questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician’s office due to intermittent bleeding from the right breast for the past several weeks. She has had no recent trauma or unprotected sexual intercourse. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 4 days with light flow. The last menstrual cycle was 1 week ago. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and she states that she drinks alcohol occasionally. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother at age 60. Vitals are within normal limits. Breast examination shows no palpable mass, skin changes or nipple retraction. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. When pressure is applied to the right breast, reddish-brown fluid is expressed from the nipple. Which of the following histopathologic findings is most likely to be seen on biopsy of this patient’s right breast?

choices.text: Branching fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells
Necrotic fat, bleeding, and giant cells
Large cells with clear cytoplasm infiltrating the nipple
Proliferating ductal elements nests in loose fibrous tissue

questions.solution:
Nipple discharge is among the most common breast complaints. It can be further divided according to the etiology, including lactational, physiologic (e.g., medication, neurological stimuli, etc.), and pathologic. Any discharge other than milk should raise suspicion for pathologic processes. These include serous (clear or yellow), sanguineous (bloody), or serosanguineous (blood-tinged). The most common cause of pathologic nipple discharge is intraductal papilloma, as seen in this patient.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 
 
Intraductal papilloma is a benign growth of papillary cells that grow into the lumen of the lactiferous ducts. It frequently presents as isolated, painless serous/bloody nipple discharge. Occasionally, it may present as a mass and/or tenderness. Mammography is mostly unrevealing or may show duct ectasia, calcifications, or a mass. Ultrasound may be more sensitive than mammography and show duct ectasia, nodules, or a cyst. MRI is the best modality to detect intraductal papilloma. On gross examination, it appears as a lobulated, soft, tan mass within a cystic cavity. Microscopically, it consists of a central, branching fibrovascular core with an overlying layer of epithelium. Although it is considered a benign lesion, it can harbor areas of atypia or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), and thus it is associated with a slightly increased risk for breast cancer. A biopsy is required for diagnosis. When biopsy demonstrates intraductal papilloma with atypical cells, surgical excision is warranted.  

Option Analysis

✅ Branching fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Necrotic fat, bleeding, and giant cells :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with fat necrosis, a benign breast lesion that occurs in the setting of trauma or surgery. Patients often present with a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis often mimics malignancy on imaging and physical examination, and thus a biopsy is needed. The absence of a palpable mass and the presence of bleeding favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Acini and stromal fibrosis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with sclerosing adenosis, a subtype of fibrocystic changes characterized by an increase in fibrous tissue and glandular cells within the lobules. Patients typically present with unilateral or bilateral, poorly-defined, tender, and lumpy breasts. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Large cells with clear cytoplasm infiltrating the nipple:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Paget's disease of the breast, which is an extension of underlying DCIS/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. Although Paget's disease can present with bleeding, the absence of eczema or a palpable mass on physical examination makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Proliferating ductal elements nests in loose fibrous tissue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with fibroadenoma, a benign tumor of the breast, commonly seen in women in reproductive age. Patients often present with a small, well-defined mobile mass on physical examination. This patient has no palpable mass on physical examination, and the presence of bleeding makes fibroadenoma less likely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic following an abnormal mammogram showing calcifications in the right breast. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. She does not smoke or use alcohol excessively, and she has not experienced weight loss, fever, or trauma. She is referred for a biopsy, which confirms the diagnosis of benign fat necrosis. However, during the biopsy, another area suspected of malignancy is found. The results of the biopsy of this additional are are shown below:  



Reproduced from: flickr

This type of cancer is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings are consistent with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), which is typically clinically and radiographically silent and is almost always an incidental finding.  

LCIS is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), it is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography. Approximately 1/3 of women diagnosed with LCIS eventually develop invasive carcinoma. It is important to note that invasive carcinomas following a diagnosis of LCIS may arise in either breast (unlike DCIS, which predisposes to invasive carcinoma in the same breast). On histology, the tumor has a homogeneous appearance. The cells are monomorphic with round nuclei and are found in clusters within the lobules. The tumor is typically ER-positive and rarely shows overexpression of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). Treatment may include close observation and radiologic follow-up, chemoprevention with tamoxifen, and rarely, bilateral prophylactic mastectomy.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rare metastases:
Incorrect: Tubular carcinoma is a rare type of ER-positive/HER2- negative cancer accounting for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. The majority of cases are detected on mammography as a small irregular mass. On histology, cells are arranged in well-formed tubules. Metastases to the lymph nodes are rare, and the prognosis is excellent. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Aggressive behavior:
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Lymphatic and vascular invasion:
Incorrect: Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare and highly aggressive form of breast cancer. Patients typically present with a red, tender and indurated breast with dimpling of the skin follicles that resembles an orange peel (peau d’orange). The classic skin appearance is caused due to invasion of the tumor to the skin lymphatic system. On histology, inflammatory carcinoma is poorly differentiated, diffusely infiltrative and obstructs the dermal lymphatic. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Invasion to the overlying skin:
Incorrect: Paget disease of the breast is an extension of ductal carcinoma in situ to the overlying skin of the nipple. Patients often present with scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated oozing lesions that resemble eczema. On histology, clusters of malignant, intraepithelial Paget cells (adenocarcinoma cells) can be found within the epidermis of the nipple. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
✅ Bilateral disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to an abnormal calcification that was observed on routine screening mammography. She is currently asymptomatic, and medical history is remarkable only for hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a fixed, non-tender, palpable lump is noted in the left breast. There are no skin changes or nipple discharge. The biopsy results are shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with abnormal mammography results and a non-tender, fixed mass, all raising concerns for an underlying malignancy. The biopsy results show an intraductal lesion with central necrosis, characteristics of a comedo-type ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or comedocarcinoma.  

A comedo-type DCIS is a distinct, microinvasive subtype of breast cancer characterized by extensive necrosis, high-grade tumor cells, and aggressive behavior. The lesion plugs the lactiferous ducts, and examination of transected ducts yields toothpaste-like necrotic tissue when pressure is applied. Microinvasive breast carcinoma refers to invasive carcinoma of the breast with an invasive focus no larger than 1 mm. The majority of these are DCIS types. Microinvasive lesions are usually treated with breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy. However, mastectomy is often preferred in patients with a large comedo-type DCIS component and high-grade lesions due to the risk of recurrence.   

Option Analysis

❌ Intraductal papilloma  :
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a benign tumor of papillary cells within the lactiferous ducts. Patients typically present with unilateral, painless, bloody nipple discharge. On histology, it is composed of a fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells. Although mostly benign, it is associated with a slightly increased risk for cancer. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive lobular carcinomas are the 2nd most common type of invasive breast cancer. Patients often present with a palpable mass and/or mass on imaging. On histology, invasive lobular carcinomas are similar to LCIS and often show characteristic cells aligned in a “single-file.”  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Comedocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma is an uncommon type of breast cancer, comprising ~2% of invasive breast cancers. On physical examination and imaging, it is characterized as a well-circumscribed tumor that is difficult to distinguish from benign tumors such as fibroadenoma. On histology, it is composed of large, anaplastic cells growing in sheets with adjacent lymphocytes and plasma cells. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast lump. A suspicious mass is found on mammogram, which is followed by a core needle biopsy that confirms the diagnosis of invasive carcinoma. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient’s mother died of breast cancer, and her sister was recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer; the doctor suspects a hereditary mutation. In healthy individuals, the involved gene has which of the following roles?

choices.text: Promotes cell proliferation via tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
This patient, who is now diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, has 2 first degree relatives who were diagnosed with breast cancer, raising concerns for hereditary causes. The majority of cases of inherited breast cancer and/or ovarian cancers are caused by a pathogenic variant in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. These genes normally encode for proteins essential for repair of DNA damage and are expressed in many cells and tissues. Therefore, cells with defective versions of these genes develop chromosomal breaks and severe aneuploidy, ultimately leading to uncontrolled proliferation and malignant transformation. While the age of onset, degree of penetrance, and susceptibility to develop other types of cancers differ among BRCA1 and BRCA2 germline mutations, most carriers will develop breast cancer by the age of 70 years (vs. 12% of women with an average risk of breast cancer).  

Option Analysis

✅ DNA repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cell cycle regulation:
Incorrect: Tumor protein p53 (TP53) is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the transcription factor p53, which is responsible for cell cycle regulation. Mutations in TP53 are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a hereditary condition that is characterized by multiple malignancies at an early age, including sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemias, and adrenal cancers. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to a BRCA1/2 mutation.  
❌ Negative regulation of signal transduction  :
Incorrect: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) is a tumor suppressor gene and a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway, which is critical for cell proliferation, cell cycle progression, and apoptosis. Carriers of this mutation are at risk for breast, endometrial, and thyroid cancer. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to a BRCA1/2 mutation.  
❌ Promotes cell proliferation via tyrosine kinase:
Incorrect: HER2 is a tyrosine kinase receptor that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by activating the RAS and (PI3K)-AKT signaling pathways. Mutations in the gene that encodes for HER2 result in overexpression of this receptor, which is associated with highly proliferative tumors and poor prognosis. However, HER2-positive breast cancer is not inherited and is considered a somatic genetic mutation. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an inherited cancer syndrome, most likely BRCA1/2.
❌ Mismatch repair:
Incorrect: Mismatch repair genes (e.g., MSH2, MLH1, MSH6, PMS2) are associated with Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). Lynch syndrome causes colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer, but it is not associated with breast cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes for a follow-up meeting after she was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma breast cancer. A 2-cm spiculated lesion was seen on mammography and confirmed with biopsy. She would like to know what the prognosis is for her condition. Which of the following findings is the worse prognostic factor for her conditions?
questions.solution:
A prognostic factor is able to provide information about the clinical outcome at the time of diagnosis, regardless of therapy. By contrast, a predictive factor is able to provide information on the response of a given therapeutic modality. For women with non-metastatic, newly diagnosed breast cancer the following factors are often used to determine the prognosis:    
  •  Age and race - Both younger (<35 years) and older age (>65 years) at the time of diagnosis is associated with a worse prognosis. Black women tend to have a worse prognosis compared to white women.  
  •  Pathologic factors include tumor stage, histological grade and tumor morphology. Breast cancer is staged according to tumor size, lymph nodes involvement, and metastatic disease (Tumor, Node, Metastasis [TNM] system). Tumor size < 2 cm and the absence of lymph node involvement or metastasis is associated with a better prognosis. In general, staging is considered a more important prognostic factor than grading, hence, among the answers above, a large tumor size is the worst prognostic factor. Tumor morphology is also important; for example, inflammatory breast cancer is associated with a poorer prognosis.  
  •  Tissue markers - Estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) expression are generally associated with better outcomes, while overexpression and/or amplification of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is associated with a poorer prognosis.  




Option Analysis

❌ HER2 receptor underexpression:
Incorrect: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is part of the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family with tyrosine kinase activity that is involved in cell signaling and proliferation. Overexpression of HER2 is associated with poor prognosis, not underexpression.   
❌ High grade of cellular differentiation  :
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (well differentiated) to high grade (poorly differentiated, or anaplastic). A tumor that is poorly differentiated does not resemble the tissue of origin. However, although poorly differentiated tumors are associated with poor prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.   
❌ High mitotic activity  :
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (low mitotic activity, well differentiated) to high grade (high mitotic activity, poorly differentiated or anaplastic). A tumor that has high mitotic activity is rapidly dividing, and therefore carries a worse prognosis. However, although poorly differentiated tumors are associated with poor prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.   
✅ Large tumor size:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 1:1 nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio:
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (well differentiated) to high grade (poorly differentiated or anaplastic). Anaplasia is the lack of differentiation. Anaplastic cells often display certain morphologic features including 1:1 nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, pleomorphism (size and shape), nuclear abnormalities, tumor giant cells, atypical mitoses, and loss of polarity. Although anaplastic tumors are associated with a poorer prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to an itchy, oozing rash from the left nipple for the past few weeks. It first started as a small ulcer which then spread to the areola, with a copious clear yellowish exudative discharge. Medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis, for which she takes nasal corticosteroids and antihistamines as needed. She has tried some steroid cream, but she did not notice any improvement. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the left nipple is ulcerated and oozing yellowish fluid. There is no palpable mass, and the right nipple appears normal. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an ulcerated, oozing lesion of the nipple, raising concerns for an underlying condition. Although further evaluation is required for a definitive diagnosis, from the answers above, only underlying adenocarcinoma can present as Paget disease of the breast (PDB).  

PDB refers to a scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion affecting the nipple and areola as a direct extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ to the overlying skin. Nipple pain, nipple retraction, bloody discharge and/or pruritus may also be present. Some patients can present without a mammogram or mass on a physical exam. Patients should be evaluated with imaging and biopsy. Nipple scrape cytology is sufficient for diagnosis, but full-thickness wedge or punch biopsy of the nipple is often performed to establish the diagnosis. Wedge biopsy, which includes the lactiferous ducts, can help identify underlying ductal carcinoma as the etiology. The histologic hallmark of PDB is the presence of clusters of malignant, intraepithelial Paget cells (adenocarcinoma cells) within the epidermis of the nipple.  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Intertrigo:
Incorrect: Intertrigo, or intertriginous dermatitis, is an inflammatory condition of skin folds characterized by moist, red-brown lesions that are accompanied by pruritus and tenderness. It is often caused by a candida yeast infection. This patient has no involvement of the skin folds, and intertrigo would be improved with topical steroid cream.   
❌ Mastitis :
Incorrect: Mastitis is an inflammation of the breast tissue that can occur in the setting of nipple injury from breastfeeding or inflammation of the subareolar ducts as periductal mastitis. Symptoms include pain, redness, fever, myalgia, with/without reactive axillary lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves symptomatic treatment, antibiotics, and continuation of breastfeeding. This patient has an oozing rash, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Eczema :
Incorrect: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is an inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, poorly-defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and oozing rash during the acute stage. Chronic inflammation ultimately results in skin thickening (lichenification). Although this patient’s rash can be explained by eczema, eczema has a predilection for the skin flexures rather than the nipple, and topical steroid cream usually improves the symptoms.   
✅ Adenocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that grows within lactiferous ducts, commonly, beneath the areola. It usually presents with serous or bloody nipple discharge. Intraductal papilloma is associated with a slight increase in risk for cancer. However, an intraductal papilloma would not explain this patient’s oozing, ulcerated lesion.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the office following abnormal results of screening mammography. The mammogram showed suspicious microcalcifications. The patient is in good health, and medical history is unremarkable. Family history is negative for cancer. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are no breast changes, palpable masses, or lymphadenopathy. There is no nipple discharge. She is scheduled for a biopsy. Based on these features alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with clinically silent disease and microcalcifications on mammography which require further evaluation with biopsy. In light of the absence of a palpable mass and the presence of calcifications seen on mammography, the most likely diagnosis is ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).  

DCIS is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lactiferous ducts and does not cross the basement membrane. Up to 90% of the women with DCIS are diagnosed following abnormal mammography showing suspicious microcalcifications; DCIS accounts for approximately 80% of all breast cancers presenting with calcifications. Findings such as a palpable mass or other soft tissue changes are less common. The prognosis is excellent, but without treatment, DCIS progresses to invasive cancer in approximately 1/3 of cases (usually in the same breast and quadrant). Therapy usually includes surgery, radiation therapy, and adjuvant endocrine therapy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. It is typically clinically and radiographically silent and is almost always an incidental finding. The presence of LCIS in one breast increases the risk for invasive breast cancer in both breasts. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), LCIS is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography.   
❌ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive lobular carcinomas are the 2nd most common type of invasive breast cancer. Patients often present with a palpable mass and/or mass on imaging. However, the absence of a palpable mass makes this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer and arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the ducts, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. It often arises from an underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Invasive ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable, irregular mass upon examination, which are absent in this patient.   
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that grows within lactiferous ducts, commonly beneath the areola. It commonly presents with isolated serous or bloody nipple discharge. Occasionally, it may present as a mass and/or tenderness. Mammography is mostly unrevealing but may show duct ectasia, calcifications, or a mass. This patient has no nipple changes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to right breast erythema and tenderness that have progressed over the past 2 weeks. She is generally healthy and has not experienced any trauma in the area. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Family history is negative for cancer. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the skin on the right breast is indurated and thickened with dimpling of the hair follicles. A palpable lymph node is present in the right axilla. The nipple appears normal. A core needle biopsy reveals an invasive carcinoma. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has an invasive carcinoma. Skin thickening, induration, and dimpling of the hair follicles depict a classic picture of peau d'orange (orange peel) of inflammatory breast cancer due to tumor obstruction to the skin lymphatics. “Inflammatory” is a misnomer, as true inflammation is absent.  

Inflammatory breast cancer is rare and the most aggressive form of breast cancer, which accounts for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers diagnosed in the United States. At the time of presentation, the majority of patients already have lymph node involvement, and one-third have distant metastases. Patients often present with breast pain or a rapidly growing breast lump. Inflammatory breast cancer is associated with poor prognosis and high rates of early recurrence. On histology, inflammatory carcinoma is poorly differentiated, diffusely infiltrative and obstructs the dermal lymphatics.  

Option Analysis

❌ Involvement the suspensory ligaments:
Incorrect: The suspensory ligaments (also known as Cooper's ligaments) is a connective tissue that helps maintain the structural integrity of the breast and is connected to the skin. Tumor invasion of the suspensory ligaments is the cause of skin dimpling at the area of tumor invasion. This patient instead had dimpling of the hair follicles, a characteristic appearance of inflammatory breast cancer.    
❌ Shortening of the lactiferous ducts:
Incorrect: The lactiferous ducts arise from the lobules of the mammary gland and converge into the nipple. Shortening of the lactiferous ducts causes nipple inversion and/or nipple discharge often seen with different types of subareolar or central malignancies but also in benign conditions such as duct ectasia, periductal mastitis, and subareolar abscess. The nipple in this case appears normal.   
✅ Obstruction of the skin lymphatics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial invasion:
Incorrect: Bacterial invasion is the cause of mastitis that may progress to form breast abscess. Both conditions usually present with a firm, red, painful, and swollen area. Breast abscess also causes a local fluctuant and palpable mass, with concomitant systemic symptoms (e.g. fever).   
❌ Trauma to chest:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis is a benign breast lesion that typically occurs in the setting of trauma or surgery. Patients often present with a firm and irregular mass. Since many patients do not recall the trauma, and certain features of the lesion on physical exam and imaging resemble malignancy (e.g. calcifications), a biopsy is often required. On histology, fat necrosis is seen as necrotic fat and giant cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 0 para 0, comes to the office after noticing a painful breast lump in the right breast on self-examination. The patient did notice that the lump becomes larger and tender closer to menstruation, and it often self-resolves once the period has ended.  Medical history is unremarkable, she takes no medication, and she has not had any recent trauma. Family history is positive for breast cancer in her mother at age 60. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a nodular lump is present in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast accompanied by diffuse tenderness. No discharge is expressible from either nipple. No lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a painful, nodular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast that is influenced by hormonal changes, favoring the diagnosis of fibrocystic changes.   

Fibrocystic changes refer to the development of fibrous tissue and cystic spaces within the breast. These changes include cysts, fibrosis, and apocrine metaplasia. The cysts arise within the lobular unit and are affected by hormones (e.g. estrogen). Growth or rupture of these cysts induces inflammation and fibrosis of the surrounding tissue -- hence the name “fibrocystic changes.” The cysts are lined by a layer of luminal cells that often undergo apocrine metaplasia.  

Fibrocystic changes are common in premenopausal women 20-50 years old. Patients often present with unilateral/bilateral/multifocal, painful, poorly-defined nodular/lumpy tissue, typically in the upper outer quadrant. Diagnosis can be made clinically but definitive diagnosis requires imaging and biopsy.  

Fibrocystic change by itself is benign and carries no risk for invasive carcinoma; however, certain features, if present on biopsy, are associated with increased risk for cancer (shown in the table below).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Fibroadenoma:
Incorrect: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast lesion typically seen in women < 35 years of age which presents as a small, well-defined, and mobile mass on physical examination. Fibroadenoma is a benign solid tumor containing glandular and fibrous tissue. Similar to fibrocystic changes, it varies in size under the hormonal influence of estrogen; however, fibroadenoma is a well-defined mass rather than a nodular lump, as seen in this patient.    
❌ Fat necrosis:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis, and the patient may not recall the specific trauma. Fat necrosis can be difficult to distinguish from a malignant mass, and biopsy is often required. Fat necrosis is not nodular and does not vary in size with the menstrual cycle.   
✅ Fibrocystic changes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that commonly grows within lactiferous ducts beneath the areola. It typically presents with unilateral serous or bloody nipple discharge, rather than a nodular mass as seen in this patient.  
❌ Breast abscess:
Incorrect: A breast abscess is a collection of inflammatory exudate (i.e. pus) within the breast. It can occur in the setting of mastitis or cellulitis that is left untreated or does not respond to antibiotic treatment. Patients often present with localized, painful inflammation of the breast accompanied by fever and malaise. The abscess is typically fluctuant and tender. This patient’s presentation and exam findings favor another diangosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast mass she noticed while showering. The patient is healthy, and she has no significant medical history. She is concerned because she recently found out she is a carrier of BRCA1 mutation. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 48 and her sister at 46 years. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol excessively. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a well-circumscribed, soft non-tender mass is palpated in the right breast. There are no nipple or skin changes, and no palpable lymph nodes. A core-needle biopsy is obtained and reveals sheets of large anaplastic cells with dense lymphocytic infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has carcinoma with medullary features, a special type of triple-negative cancer comprising approximately 5% of invasive breast cancers. Triple-negative means negative for estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and excess HER2 protein. Clinically, it presents as a soft, palpable, circumscribed mass which may appear with or without lymphadenopathy. It is often seen as a round, oval or lobulated mass on mammography, which makes it hard to distinguish from benign tumors. On histology, it is characterized by a syncytial growth pattern, with large sheets of anaplastic cells with prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and some areas of necrosis. The tumor cells are usually poorly differentiated (high-grade). This type of carcinoma is often associated with germline BRCA1 mutations; however, the majority of cancers in patients with BRCA1 gene mutations are not medullary. The prognosis for carcinoma with medullary features seems to be more favorable than that of infiltrating ductal carcinomas, despite their aggressive histologic appearance.  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

❌ Comedocarcinoma :
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. Transected ducts produce cheese-like necrotic tissue that extrudes when gentle pressure is applied.   
❌ Fibroadenoma :
Incorrect: Fibroadenoma is the most common benign tumor of the breast, commonly seen in women in reproductive age. Patients often present with a small, well-defined, mobile mass on physical examination. On histology, it is characterized by nests of proliferation of the ductal elements embedded in a fibrous stroma. Although clinically fibroadenoma is difficult to distinguish from medullary breast cancer, the histology results in this case excluded this diagnosis.   
❌ Phyllodes tumor:
Incorrect: Phyllodes tumors are uncommon fibroepithelial breast tumors that typically present as a painless smooth, multinodular, well-defined, firm and mobile mass. On histology, the tumor is characterized by “phyllodes” (Greek for “leaflike”) growth pattern with bulbous nodules of proliferating stromal cells covered by epithelium. Phyllodes are typically seen in the 5th decade. This patient’s age and histological findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Medullary carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable irregular mass upon examination. On histology, the appearance varies from well-developed tubules to sheets of anaplastic cells. The histological presence of lymphocytic infiltrate and soft mass on physical examination favors another diagnosis in this case.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the office after discovering a lump in the left breast. She first noticed the mass on self-examination several weeks ago. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She drinks alcohol socially and does not use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a tender, circumscribed mass is palpated at the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The patient is referred for biopsy, and the results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fibroadenoma, the most common benign tumor in the breast, accounting for 50% of all breast biopsies. It is commonly found in women between the ages of 15 and 35 years. Simple fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of glandular as well as fibrous tissue. It typically presents as a small, well-defined, mobile mass; however, multiple fibroadenomas may occur in the same breast or bilaterally. The etiology of fibroadenomas remains unclear, but a hormonal association has been established as they persist during the reproductive years (when estrogen levels are high), increase in size during pregnancy or with estrogen therapy, and regress after menopause (when estrogen levels become low). On ultrasound, fibroadenomas are seen as a well-defined solid mass. They can be managed with 3-6 months of ultrasound follow-up or a core needle biopsy for definitive diagnosis. On biopsy, it is characterized by a mixture of proliferating ductal elements (adenoma) nested in loose fibrous tissue (fibroma).  

Option Analysis

✅ Fibroadenoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fat necrosis:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis, though the patient may not recall the specific trauma. Fat necrosis can be difficult to clinically distinguish from a malignant mass, and biopsy is often required. On histology, necrotic fat and giant cells are expected.  

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   
❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) refers to a localized tumor that arises from monoclonal proliferation of the terminal duct cells which ductal lumen; by definition, the tumor does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS is typically recognized incidentally on mammogram screening as microcalcifications and rarely as a stony hard mass on physical examination.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Paget disease:
Incorrect: Paget disease refers to an extension of underlying DCIS or invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and contiguous skin of the nipple, which presents as eczematous  patches over the nipple and areolar skin. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 70-year-old African-American woman, gravida 3 para 3, comes to the clinic due to a breast mass found on self-examination. She is generally healthy and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week and 4-5 cups of coffee per day. Menarche was at age 12 and first pregnancy at age 22. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her maternal aunt at age 55. The patient’s father had colon cancer at age of 60. The patient has never been very physically active. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a fixed, palpable firm mass is noted in the left breast. Mammogram shows a suspicious mass with calcifications. Core needle biopsy is performed and confirms the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ. While discussing treatment options, the patient asks the doctor why she developed this condition. Which of the following confers the most significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in biological females and the leading cause of cancer death in females worldwide. In the United States, it is the most frequent malignancy in biological females and the 2nd leading cause of death. Risk factors can be further divided into modifiable (e.g. smoking) and non modifiable (e.g. age). Among the answers above, the patient’s age is associated with the most significant increase in risk for breast cancer. At age 70 and older, 1 in 15 women develops breast cancer. Risk factors for developing breast cancer are depicted in the table below.    



Option Analysis

✅ Patient's age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patient's race:
Incorrect: White women have the highest rate of breast cancer, while black women are more likely to present with regional or advanced disease. However, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.    
❌ Patient's physical activity:
Incorrect: Currently, there is no evidence that lack of physical activity increases the risk for breast cancer. On the other hand, regular physical exercise does appear to provide protection against breast cancer, espcially in postmenopausal women. However, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.  
❌ Patient's family history:
Incorrect: Positive family history of breast cancer in a first-degree relative is strongly associated with increased risk, especially if the relative was diagnosed before the age of 30. The risk is also affected by the number of first-degree relatives diagnosed with breast cancer. Instead of a first-degree relative, this patient’s maternal aunt had breast cancer, making family history a less significant risk factor in this patient. Additionally, this patient has another, more significant risk factor for the development of breast cancer.    
❌ Patient's obstetric history:
Incorrect: Multiparity confers a protective effect against breast cancer, which is theorized to occur due to the decreased levels of estrogen during pregnancy and lactation. Nulliparous women are at increased risk for breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician's office due to suspicious findings seen on a routine mammogram. She recalls no recent trauma or breast surgery. She is a gymnastics teacher and regularly engages in intense workout regimens. The patient’s first mammogram 2 years ago was normal. Medical history is unremarkable except hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother diagnosed at age 64. On physical examination, a lump is palpated in the right breast field. Mammography results are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

 

After a discussion with the physician, the patient subsequently undergoes biopsy, and the results are shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a suspicious mass showing calcifications on mammography. Her biopsy results, however, reveal fat globules and associated necrosis, confirming the diagnosis of fat necrosis.   

Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis. However, many patients do not have a recollection of the specific trauma, although they may often be involved in activities where trauma is likely to occur (e.g. gymnastics). On mammography and ultrasound, findings such as oil cysts (collections of liquefied fat) are often seen. Fat necrosis is often confused with malignancy on physical examination as well as on radiologic studies showing calcification. Therefore, a biopsy is often required to exclude other conditions. On histology, necrotic fat and giant cells are seen. After the diagnosis has been established, excision is not required, since there is no increased risk for cancer.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive lesion that arises from terminal duct lobular units of the breast. It is characterized by a solid proliferation of small cells with uniform, round nuclei, and variably distinct cell borders. LCIS is found in the majority of cases as an incidental finding that is diagnosed on a breast biopsy performed for another reason, such as fibrocystic change or fibroadenoma. This patient's presentation, imaging, and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Sclerosing adenosis:
Incorrect: Sclerosing adenosis is a subtype of fibrocystic changes, characterized by an increase in fibrous tissue and glandular cells within the lobules. While fibrocystic change is usually a benign condition, sclerosing adenosis subtype is associated with a slightly increased risk for invasive cancer. Sclerosing adenosis can present with calcifications on mammography; however, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Fat necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), refers to a localized tumor that arises from monoclonal proliferation of the terminal duct cells which fill the ductal lumen; by definition, the tumor does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS is typically recognized incidentally on mammogram screening as microcalcifications and rarely as a hard, palpable lump on physical examination. Although this patient’s mammogram shows calcifications, the biopsy results favor another diagnosis.  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma is an uncommon type of breast cancer, comprising about 2% of invasive breast cancers. On physical examination and imaging, it is characterized as a well-circumscribed tumor that is difficult to distinguish from benign tumors such as fibroadenoma. On histology, it is composed of large, anaplastic cells growing in sheets with adjacent lymphocytes and plasma cells. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic after noticing a lump under the left nipple. He is in good health and takes no medications. Family history is positive for breast cancer in his mother, who was diagnosed at age 40. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. He is 180 cm tall (5’9’’), and BMI is 24.7 kg/m2. On physical examination, a painless, firm subareolar mass is palpated. No gynecomastia is present. Examination of the testicles reveals no abnormalities. Mammography shows irregular microcalcifications in the left breast. Subsequent core needle biopsy confirms the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Mutation in the tumor protein p53

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a subareolar mass which is subsequently revealed to be breast cancer on biopsy. Breast cancer in men is very rare; however, similar to breast cancer in women, a positive family history of breast cancer in a first-degree relative is associated with an increased risk for developing breast cancer in men. As with breast cancer in women, the breast/ovarian cancer genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2 (autosomal dominant inheritance pattern) are responsible for the majority of known cases of hereditary breast cancer. BRCA1 mutations occur rarely, with the exception of individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish ethnicity. Both genes are involved in the homologous recombination DNA repair pathway and are normally expressed in many cells and tissues throughout the body. All men who are diagnosed with breast cancer should be referred for genetic counseling and BRCA mutation testing.   

Other risk factors for developing breast cancer in men include alterations of the estrogen-to-androgen ratio (e.g., Klinefelter syndrome, hormonal therapies) and other genetic conditions such as PTEN tumor suppressor gene mutations (Cowden syndrome), and tumor protein p53 mutations (Li-Fraumeni syndrome). These are far more rare than BRCA2 mutations.  

Patients often present with a painless, firm, subareolar mass with nipple involvement. Men tend to present with more advanced stages than female breast cancer, likely due to a lack of awareness. The majority of men are diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinomas subtypes, while lobular carcinomas are extremely rare. Evaluation includes a physical examination, mammography, and biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment may include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy and endocrine therapy. Men are usually treated with mastectomy rather than lumpectomy, due to limited breast tissue.  

Option Analysis

❌ Presence of inactivated X chromosome:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is a rare condition caused by inheritance of an additional X chromosome. It is characterized by tall habitus, long extremities, atrophic testes, gynecomastia, and a high ratio of estrogen to testosterone. Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at increased risk for breast cancer; however, this patient has none of the clinical features.   
❌ Excess Y chromosome:
Incorrect: Double Y males (47, XYY) are phenotypically normal and often are not diagnosed. Patients are typically very tall and have normal fertility. The karyotype may be associated with a learning disability, severe acne, and autism spectrum disorders. It is not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.   
❌ Mutation in BRCA1 gene:
Incorrect: Germline mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes account for 50% of familial breast cancer. Women with BRCA1 mutations have a higher risk of developing epithelial ovarian cancers, while men have a higher risk of developing prostate cancer. BRCA1 mutations can also cause breast cancer in men, but a BRCA2 mutation is the far more common cause of male breast cancer.   
✅ Mutation in BRCA2 gene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Mutation in the tumor protein p53  :
Incorrect: Tumor protein p53 (TP53) is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the transcription factor p53, which is responsible for cell cycle regulation. Mutation in TP53 is associated with Li–Fraumeni syndrome, a hereditary condition that is characterized by multiple malignancies at an early age, including sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemias, and adrenal cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to breast changes. During the past few months, she has noticed skin dimpling over the right breast which has slowly increased. She has previously been in good health, eats a balanced diet and exercises regularly. Family history is negative for breast cancer. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, skin dimpling is noticed on the right upper quadrant of the right breast. A firm, fixed mass is palpated at the same location. Mammography reveals a 2 cm, dense mass with spiculated margins. A core-needle biopsy is obtained and shows sheets of anaplastic cells with an extensive desmoplastic response. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has an invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), the most common type of breast cancer, accounting for up to 80% of invasive cancers. It is important to note that the term IDC is used for all carcinomas that are not subclassified into specialized types (e.g., mucinous, tubular). The tumor usually arises from ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and crosses the basement membrane. Ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable irregular mass upon examination. On histology, its appearance ranges from tumors with well-developed tubules to sheets of anaplastic cells. About 60% of the tumors are ER-positive, 20% HER2 positive, and 15% are negative for both.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), it is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography. On histology, the tumor has a homogeneous appearance. The cells are monomorphic with round nuclei and are found in clusters within the lobules. LCIS is not associated with an extensive desmoplastic response and is unlikely to be observed on mammography.   
❌ Comedo carcinoma:
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. Transected ducts produce toothpaste-like necrotic tissue that extrudes when gentle pressure is applied to the breast.  
❌ Tubular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Tubular carcinoma is a rare type of ER-positive/HER2- negative cancer accounting for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. The majority of cases are detected on mammography as a small irregular mass. On histology, cells are arranged in well-formed tubules. Metastases to the lymph nodes are rare, and the prognosis is excellent. In about 3/4 of the cases, a low grade associated ductal carcinoma in situ is present.   
✅ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mucinous carcinoma:
Incorrect: Mucinous (colloid) carcinoma is an ER-positive/HER2- negative tumor that constitutes up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. On gross examination, it has a gelatinous appearance and is well-circumscribed. On histology, nests of tumor cells dispersed in extracellular mucin can be seen. It is considered a prognostically favorable variant among invasive breast cancers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up appointment after a core-needle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of breast cancer. The results are sent for further immunohistochemistry analysis. The patient would like to know the prognosis of her condition. Which of the following characteristics, if found, would confer the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer prognosis is dependent on the cancer stage, biological type of tumor, and the availability of treatment modalities. Invasive carcinomas can be classified according to the biologic type as follows: ER-positive/HER2-negative, HER2-positive, and ER/PR/HER2-negative (triple-negative). The biologic classification is important, since each type differs in patient characteristics, grade, mutation profile, metastatic pattern, response to therapy, time to recurrence, and prognosis. For the majority of patients with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, an adjuvant endocrine therapy is recommended. Patients with triple negative tumors tend to have a poorer short-term prognosis (first five to seven years) and higher relapse rates during this period of time compared with ER-positive types. Since triple-negative tumors lack hormone receptors, no targeted therapy is available, making treatment more difficult.  





Option Analysis

❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  +  -  - :
Incorrect: Estrogen receptor (ER) expression is generally associated with a better outcome and prognosis. ER is used to determine if a patient should receive adjuvant endocrine therapy (e.g. tamoxifen).
✅   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression -  -  - :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  +  +  - :
Incorrect: In general, both estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) expression are associated with a better outcome and prognosis. ER is used to determine if a patient should receive adjuvant endocrine therapy. Progesterone receptor (PR)-positive tumors also have better outcomes with endocrine therapy; however, PR status is heavily dependent on ER. Therefore, PR is not an independent predictive value.
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  - +  - :
Incorrect: Progesterone receptor (PR)-positive tumors have better outcomes with endocrine therapy; however, PR status is heavily dependent on ER. Therefore, PR is not an independent predictive value. 
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  -  - +:
Incorrect: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) overexpression and/or amplification confers an unfavorable prognosis. Before the introduction of targeted therapy such as molecular inhibitors of HER2 (e.g. trastuzumab), outcomes were similar to patients with triple-negative carcinomas.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to progressive chest enlargement. He first noted it 1 year ago while showering in school after physical education class. Since then, it has increased in size, and he became embarrassed after being teased by his friends. He was born at term after a normal pregnancy via vaginal delivery. His development has been uneventful, and all milestones have been reached. Medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis, for which he takes fluticasone nasal spray and oral loratadine. He has had no headaches or visual changes. He does not smoke, drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight; BMI is 21. Physical examination reveals bilateral firm masses extending concentrically from the nipple. The mass is more prominent on the right side. Sexual development is Tanner stage 4. The rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Medication side effects; stopping the medication will resolve the condition
Hypogonadism; hormonal treatment will resolve the condition.
Increased fat deposition; observation is indicated.

questions.solution:
This adolescent boy is presenting with isolated gynecomastia, as well as normal physical examination and development, favoring the diagnosis of physiological gynecomastia. Gynecomastia is defined as benign proliferation of the glandular breast tissue in males. It differs from the female breast development by the lack of terminal alveolar development in response to progesterone. Patients typically present with a mass or ridge of glandular tissue that is symmetrically distributed around the nipple. It may be tender or asymmetric. Gynecomastia can be physiologic or pathologic, primary (e.g. Klinefelter syndrome) or secondary (e.g. drugs). The vast majority of gynecomastia cases in children and adolescents are physiologic.  

Neonatal breast hypertrophy ー This occurs in both boys and girls during the neonatal period and is thought to be related to placental transformation of androgens to estrogens, which stimulate glandular proliferation in the fetus. Most cases resolve by one year.    

Pubertal gynecomastia ー This refers to the physiologic enlargement of the glandular breast tissue in boys during puberty. Gynecomastia peaks during mid-puberty, coinciding with peak height velocity at age 12 to 14 years, and Tanner stage 3 to 4. The pathogenesis is thought to be related to an imbalance in the androgen-to-estrogen ratio, in which a relative increase in extratesticular production of estrogen may play a role in the development of gynecomastia. While most cases of physiologic pubertal gynecomastia resolve spontaneously (typically one year of onset), management is individualized and based on the degree of psychosocial distress. Initial management often consists of reassurance and observation.  

Clinical features suspicious of pathologic gynecomastia: 
  •  Occurrence in the prepubertal stage or after puberty in boys 
  •  Rapid progression 
  •  Enlargement >4 cm (1.6 inches) in diameter 
  •  Rapid and/or precocious virilization 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication side effects; stopping the medication will resolve the condition:
Incorrect: Certain medications and drugs are associated with gynecomastia as a side effect. Examples include isoniazid, ketoconazole, ranitidine, omeprazole, etc. However, this patient is not taking any medication that is associated with gynecomastia.   
❌ Hypogonadism; hormonal treatment will resolve the condition.:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome is the most common congenital cause of primary hypogonadism. It often presents during adolescence, and up to 70% of patients with Klinefelter syndrome have gynecomastia. This child has no features of Klinefelter syndrome, such as thin body habitus, long limbs, learning and behavioral difficulties, or firm and small testes.  
❌ Tumor; MRI is indicated:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors such as Leydig, Sertoli cell tumors, and germ cell tumors may cause gynecomastia due to abnormal hormone secretion. However, patients typically present with a testicular mass that does not transilluminate. A prolactinoma of the pituitary gland can also present with gynecomastia; however, patients often complain of headaches and/or visual changes.   
✅ Hormonal imbalance; reassurance is indicated.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased fat deposition; observation is indicated. :
Incorrect: Increased fat deposition is termed pseudogynecomastia (lipomastia), a condition often seen in obese men. However, it differs from gynecomastia, which is glandular proliferation of the breast tissue rather than fat deposition. Also, this patient has a normal BMI.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman was recently referred to a medical oncologist for a newly diagnosed breast cancer. The patient had noticed a lump in her outer right breast, which prompted a lumpectomy. Pathology described the lesion as an advanced lobular carcinoma. Molecular pathology results from the lump are shown below. Which of the following is a treatment option that would inhibit the cell cycle's progression from the G1 to S phase? 

 HER2     Negative    
 Estrogen Receptor     Positive    
 CD4/6     Positive    
 CD1      Positive
questions.solution:
This patient suffers from an advanced lobular carcinoma, which is HER2-negative and ER-positive. Notably, molecular pathology shows that the tumor is positive for cyclin D 4 and 6 mutations and cyclin D1 mutations. The cyclin family of proteins is involved in normal cell cycle progression. They serve to phosphorylate the Rb protein, which then activates the E2F transcription factor driving cell phase progression. Approximately 90% of cancers express mutations in the cyclin family of proteins over time. In breast cancer cases, roughly 50-60% carry mutations in the cyclin family.  

Currently, three inhibitors of cyclin-dependent kinases exist, each targeting cyclin D4 and D1. These medications include abemaciclib, palbociclib, and ribociclib. They bind to and inhibit the action of cyclin kinases, preventing phosphorylation of Rb and preventing E2F transcription activity, thereby halting cell cycle progression. They are often used with aromatase inhibitors to treat HER2-negative breast cancers. Adverse effects include neutropenia, alopecia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Several other CDK inhibitors are currently undergoing clinical trials for various types of cancers.  

Option Analysis

✅ Abemaciclib :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bortezomib :
Incorrect: Bortezomib is a drug that inhibits proteasomes. It does not act as a cell cycle inhibitor.  
❌ Trastuzumab  :
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to HER2 receptors in breast and gastric cancers. As this is HER2-negative cancer, it is not an appropriate therapy.  
❌ Rituximab  :
Incorrect: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20, a marker of B cells. 
❌ Methotrexate :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist which binds to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

questions.text: A graduate student studies the pharmacodynamics of exemestane, a medication used to treat breast cancer. Assuming the target enzyme follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics, which of the following best describes exemestane’s binding site on the target enzyme and its effect on the target enzyme’s V<sub>max</sub> (maximum rate of enzyme activity) and K<sub>m</sub> (Michaelis constant)?
questions.solution:
Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) block estrogen formation by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme, which converts androgen to estrogen.

Aromatase inhibitors are used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal individuals. This is because, in postmenopausal women, estrogen is synthesized in the adrenal glands, muscle, fat, and skin. AIs block this pathway and suppress estrogen levels. In premenopausal women, estrogen is synthesized primarily in the ovaries and regulated by gonadotropin. As a result, administration of AIs would increase gonadotropin release secondary to reduced negative estrogen feedback on the pituitary gland, resulting in increased ovarian stimulation.

There are two main types of aromatase inhibitors. Type I AIs (e.g. exemestane) are steroidal agents that are irreversible competitive inhibitors of aromatase. They bind to aromatase’s active site. They reduce the Vmax but do not affect the Km. Type II AIs (e.g., anastrozole, letrozole) are non-steroidal agents. They are reversible competitive inhibitors that bind to the active site. They do not affect Vmax but increase the Km of aromatase.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ :
Incorrect: These parameters are consistent with those of a reversible competitive inhibitor. In contrast, exemestane is an irreversible competitive inhibitor of aromatase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive inhibitor of aromatase. The medication binds to the active site of aromatase and reduces its Vmax. It would not affect the Km, the substrate concentration needed for aromatase to reach half of its maximum rate of reaction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive aromatase inhibitor. As a result, it binds to the active site of aromatase instead of an allosteric site.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive aromatase inhibitor. As a result, it binds to the active site of aromatase instead of an allosteric site.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of a breast nodule. She first noticed the nodule one week ago while showering. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and two uncomplicated pregnancies delivered vaginally. Vital signs are temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 148/73 mmHg. Physical exam reveals a firm nodule in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Several enlarged axillary lymph nodes are palpated. Further testing reveals the patient has metastatic estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. A medication that prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogen is added to the patient’s treatment regimen. Which side effects should this patient be warned about?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on an aromatase inhibitor (AI) to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. There are two types of aromatase inhibitors. Type I AIs (e.g. exemestane) are steroidal agents that are irreversible competitive inhibitors of aromatase. Type II AIs (e.g., anastrozole, letrozole) are non-steroidal agents. They are reversible competitive inhibitors.

Both type I and II AIs are well-tolerated; however, since estrogen has a protective effect on the cardiovascular system and helps sustain bone density, patients on AIs are deprived of its protective effects. This can increase their risk of developing cardiovascular diseases and osteopenia/osteoporosis, predisposing patients to fractures. Bisphosphonates should be administered together with AIs to prevent such events.

Moreover, around 20-50% of patients develop arthralgias, manifesting as morning stiffness and hand or wrist pain. The exact cause of this side effect is unclear. However, it is hypothesized to be related to estrogen deficiency or immune-mediated inflammation.

Patients can experience menopause-like symptoms secondary to decreased estrogen levels. These include hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and loss of libido.

Letrozole, a type II AI, can also cause hair thinning. Exemestane, a type I AI, can also cause visual disturbances.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Many anti-cancer agents, ranging from methotrexate to busulfan, can cause myelosuppression. However, this patient was initiated on an aromatase inhibitor, which reduces the conversion of androgens to estrogen.  
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Taxanes, such as paclitaxel, are used to treat breast cancer. Taxanes can cause peripheral neuropathy as a side effect. Taxanes work by blocking microtubule formation.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Medications, such as doxorubicin and trastuzumab, can cause dilated cardiomyopathy as a side effect. Neither medication blocks the peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogen.  
✅ Joint pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that can cause endometrial hyperplasia as a side effect. The medication works by acting as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissue rather than blocking estrogen synthesis.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of gynecomastia, which the patient first noticed two weeks ago. The patient does not have breast tenderness or discharge. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Two months ago, the patient was started on a new antihypertensive agent that can lead to elevated serum potassium levels as a side effect. Family history is notable for breast cancer in his mother.  The patient consumes around 3-4 beers per week and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Physical examination is notable for the findings below. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
 

Image reproduced fromWikimedia Commons

choices.text: Impaired binding of androgens to its receptors

questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral gynecomastia in the setting of starting a new antihypertensive medication that can cause hyperkalemia as a side effect. He was most likely started on spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts as an aldosterone receptor antagonist. However, the medication can also bind to androgen receptors and prevent testosterone from binding. As a result, it can cause anti-androgenic side effects such as gynecomastia (the development of breasts in men) and impotence.

Gynecomastia typically resolves with the discontinuation of spironolactone. As a result, patients with this side effect can be switched to other potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., triamterene, eplerenone), or another antihypertensive agent.  

Option Analysis

❌ Malignant proliferation of breast tissue:
Incorrect: Breast cancer typically presents as a unilateral lump in the upper/outer quadrant of the affected breast. In contrast, this has bilateral breast enlargement. Hence, breast cancer is unlikely to be the cause of his gynecomastia.  
❌ Impaired hepatic breakdown of estrogen:
Incorrect: Patients with liver cirrhosis often have difficulty metabolizing estrogen and will have symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., gynecomastia, palmar erythema). Although this patient has a history of alcohol use, the extent of his consumption would not be enough to cause liver cirrhosis. Moreover, the patient lacks additional physical examination findings consistent with cirrhosis (e.g., ascites, hepatomegaly, jaundice).  
✅ Impaired binding of androgens to its receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced synthesis of dihydrotestosterone:
Incorrect: 5α-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, reduce conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). These medications can be used to treat benign prostate hyperplasia, androgenic alopecia, and hirsutism. However, they are not used to treat hypertension.  
❌ Inhibition of cholesterol desmolase:
Incorrect: Azoles, in particular ketoconazole, can inhibit the enzyme cholesterol desmolase and reduce testosterone synthesis. This can lead to gynecomastia as a side effect. However, this patient has no history of fungal infections and would unlikely be taking an azole.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because of difficulty urinating and nocturia. Digital rectal examination is performed and reveals nodular enlargement of the prostate. A biopsy is obtained and confirms adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following lymph nodes are at the greatest risk of subsequent metastasis?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma. Since lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, the cancer cells are most likely to metastasize there first.    

The lymphatic drainage of the reproductive system varies according to each organ. In females, the ovaries drain into the para-aortic lymph nodes, whereas the body of the uterus and cervix drain into the external iliac lymph nodes. The cervix and proximal vagina also drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes. In contrast, the distal vagina and vulva drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. Finally, the clitoris drains into the deep inguinal lymph nodes.    

The testes drain into the para-aortic lymph nodes in males, while the scrotum drains into the superficial inguinal nodes. The prostate and the corpus cavernosum drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes. Finally, the glans penis drains into the deep inguinal nodes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Internal iliac nodes :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial inguinal nodes :
Incorrect: Lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac nodes, not the superficial inguinal nodes.  
❌ Deep inguinal nodes:
Incorrect: The deep inguinal nodes receive lymphatic fluid from the deep portions of the lower limb, distal spongy urethra, and the clitoris in females and glans penis in males. The deep inguinal nodes do not receive lymphatic fluid from the prostate. 
❌ External iliac nodes :
Incorrect: Lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac nodes, not the external iliac nodes.  
❌ Para-aortic lymph nodes. :
Incorrect: The para-aortic lymph nodes receive lymphatic fluid from the testes in males and ovaries in females. In contrast, the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for an annual examination. The patient feels well and has no complaints. Over the past year, she has been sexually active with three male partners and does not use barrier contraception. A speculum exam is performed, and a specimen is collected using a cytobrush. Pap smear testing reveals cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. Which of the following best describes the normal histology of the region of the cervix from where this sample was obtained?

choices.text: Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells
Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cells

questions.solution:
The cervical canal can be divided into three regions. The endocervix is closer to the uterus, and is lined by columnar epithelial cells. The ectocervix is continuous with the vagina, and it is lined by mature squamous epithelial cells. Where the squamous epithelium of the ectocervix and the columnar epithelium of the endocervix meet, there is a line called the squamocolumnar junction (also termed the transformation zone).  

It is at the transformation zone where cellular metaplasia and dysplasia most often take place, and therefore a Pap smear specifically samples tissue from the squamocolumnar junction. Metaplasia occurs when a stressor, such as acidity of the vaginal canal during reproductive years, causes replacement of one cell type by another. In the cervix, columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Metaplasia is reversible once the stressor is removed.    

In contrast, dysplasia occurs when fully differentiated cells are replaced by immature cells with varying shape and nuclear morphology, as demonstrated by the koilocytes in this question stem, with their enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. Mild dysplasia is reversible. However moderate or severe dysplasia is irreversible, and if not monitored, it can progress to cervical cancer.  

Option Analysis

❌ Squamous epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Squamous epithelial cells are found in the ectocervix, which is continuous with the vagina. A Pap smear is obtained at the transformation zone, where dysplasia most frequently happens.   
❌ Cuboidal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Cuboidal epithelial cells are often found in organs with secretory, absorptive, or excretory functions. These include the pancreas, kidneys, and parotid glands. Simple cuboidal epithelium is also present on the outer surface of the ovaries. However, cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix.  
❌ Columnar epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Columnar epithelial cells are found in the endocervix, which is closer to the uterus. Koilocytes (epithelial cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos) and cervical dysplasia are more likely to be present at the transformation zone, rather than the endocervix.  
✅ Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix. Therefore, there would be no region in the cervix wherein squamous epithelial cells are replaced by cuboidal epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks gestation comes to the clinic due to abnormal facial hair growth. The patient has received consistent prenatal care and takes prenatal vitamins regularly. At the first prenatal appointment, ultrasound confirmed a twin intrauterine pregnancy with 2 normal fetal heartbeats. The patient’s medical history is unremarkable.
