Menarche was at age 14, and the patient’s menstrual cycle occurred every 28 days, lasting for 3-4 days. During the past few weeks, the patient noticed hair growth on her chin, upper lip, and abdomen. She has also experienced mild abdominal discomfort, which she assumed to be normal. Vitals signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, dark hair is noted on the face and abdomen. Pelvic examination reveals bilateral adnexal masses. Abdominal ultrasound shows a normal twin intrauterine pregnancy and bilateral multiseptated cystic adnexal masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman with a twin pregnancy is presenting with a new onset of hirsutism and bilateral complex adnexal masses, a presentation consistent with theca lutein cysts.  

Theca lutein cysts are a type of follicular cyst, characterized by hypertrophy and luteinization of the theca interna layer. Their growth is stimulated by high levels of β-hCG or due to hyper-sensitivity to β-hCG. Therefore, it is associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestation, and ovarian hyperstimulation (such as in ovulation induction therapies). The cysts are usually asymptomatic but may lead to maternal virilization, hyperemesis gravidarum, preeclampsia, or thyroid dysfunction. Treatment is usually conservative; since postpartum women have declining levels of β-hCG, spontaneous regression occurs.



Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):
Incorrect: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by bilateral, enlarged ovaries with multiple small follicular cysts classically seen in a woman who is obese, anovulatory, and hirsute. While this woman has some of these features, there is no mention of obesity and her menstrual cycle has been normal prior to pregnancy, making another diagnosis more likely.
✅ Theca lutein cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Follicular cysts:
Incorrect: Follicular cysts (also known as physiologic cysts) occur when rupture fails to occur during ovulation, and instead, the follicle continues to grow. Although benign, it may lead to hemorrhage or ovarian torsion. Follicular cysts are not associated with hirsutism or twin pregnancy. On ultrasound examination, follicular cysts are thin-walled, smooth, and unilocular.


❌ Corpus luteal cysts:
Incorrect: Corpus luteal cysts arise when the corpus luteum fails to involute and progressively enlarge following ovulation. Of note, a corpus luteum cyst is always seen in early intrauterine pregnancy and therefore called physiologic or functional. Although benign, it may become hemorrhagic, painful or lead to ovarian torsion. Corpus luteum cysts may appear simple or complex with internal debris on ultrasound.  


❌ Ovarian hyperthecosis:
Incorrect: Ovarian hyperthecosis is a condition seen typically in postmenopausal women and characterized by the presence of islands of luteinized theca cells that are scattered throughout the ovarian stroma instead of being restricted to the surrounding of the cystic follicles (as occur in PCOS). This results in an increased production of androgens. Patients may present with progressive acne and hirsutism, clitoral enlargement, male-pattern baldness, deepening of the voice, male habitus, and insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the physician for evaluation of a testicular mass, which the patient noticed a week ago while showering. The mass has not been causing pain or discomfort. However, the patient has been experiencing enlargement of the breast tissue and a decrease in facial hair. Temperature is 37.7°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 132/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a firm mass in the right testicle, which does not transilluminate with light. The cremaster reflex is present bilaterally, and there is no erythema of the scrotum. Bilateral breast enlargement is noted; palpation reveals centrally located glandular tissue and mild tenderness bilaterally. The remainder of the physical examination is non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals normal placental alkaline phosphatase, α-fetoprotein, and ꞵ-hCG levels. Which of the following findings is most likely present within the patient’s testicular mass?

choices.text: Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Epithelial, cartilage, and smooth muscle tissue
Purulent material with a neutrophil predominance
Serous fluid originating from the peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a testicular mass, symptoms of hyperestrogenism, and normal ꞵ-hCG levels. He most likely has a Leydig cell tumor of the testis. Of note, choriocarcinoma can also cause hyperestrogenism but is associated with elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.

Leydig cell tumor is a type of sex cord stromal tumor with a bimodal age distribution, affecting prepubertal indviduals and those between the ages of 30-60 years. These tumors (unlike Sertoli cell tumors) originate from outside of the seminiferous tubules.

Clinically, Leydig cell tumors can be hormonally active, meaning they can secrete both male and female sex hormones. Excess male sex hormones, like testosterone, can cause premature puberty in young males, while in adults they usually cause no symptoms. Excess female sex hormones, like estrogen, can cause feminization and delayed puberty in young males. In adults (such as in the case of this patient), because of activity in Leydig cell aromatase that transforms testosterone to estradiol, signs of hypogonadism can be seen in males, including the following: unilateral or bilateral asymmetric gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction often associated with decrease of libido, infertility with oligo- or azoospermia, and feminine hair distribution.

On gross examination, Leydig cell tumors have a golden-brown appearance. On histology, they contain Reinke crystals, which are pink, rod-like crystals found within the cellular cytoplasm.



Option Analysis

❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors present with a markedly elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP), whereas this patient’s AFP level is within normal range.
❌ Epithelial, cartilage, and smooth muscle tissue:
Incorrect: Teratomas consist of tissue from all three germinal layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. This type of tumor can contain epithelial cells, cartilage, and smooth muscle. However, teratomas would not typically manifest with the findings of hyperestrogenism (e.g., gynecomastia, decreased facial hair) as seen in this patient.
❌ Purulent material with a neutrophil predominance:
Incorrect: An infectious etiology, such as epididymitis, can lead to abscess formation and accumulation of purulent material. Patients with epididymitis typically have testicular pain and scrotal erythema, which are absent in this patient.
❌ Serous fluid originating from the peritoneal cavity:
Incorrect: Hydroceles are accumulations of serous fluid that arise due to failure of the processus vaginalis to fully obliterate. Although hydroceles can manifest as a testicular mass, they would transilluminate with light and would not cause symptoms of hyperestrogenism.
✅ Eosinophilic rod-like cytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to worsening fatigue and abdominal distention over the past 2 months. The patient has felt increasing fatigue, early satiety, and has lost 4.5 kg (10 lbs) without changes in diet. Medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus type 2 managed with metformin. The patient’s last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, bilateral adnexal masses are palpated. The vaginal exam shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows distention and shifting dullness. Hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. Histological analysis of the masses would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Tumor giant cells with bilobed nuclei
Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate
Sheets of malignant cells invading the stroma and concentric calcifications

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with ascites, bilateral adnexal masses, weight loss, and anemia, suggesting a gastric cancer with metastases to the ovaries, the so-called Krukenberg tumors. Krukenberg tumors are characterized by bilateral ovarian metastases from an undifferentiated gastric carcinoma. Although anemia is associated with many cancers, it is common in gastric cancer due to blood loss through feces.  

The majority of patients with gastric cancer are symptomatic. Weight loss and persistent abdominal pain are the most prevalent symptoms at initial diagnosis. Symptoms are location dependent and may include adenopathy (Virchow's node), ascites (peritoneal spread), palpable liver mass and jaundice, and Krukenberg tumors, as seen in this patient. On histology, Krukenberg tumor is characterized by abundant mucin-secreting, signet ring cells.  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

❌ Tumor giant cells with bilobed nuclei:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells (“owl eyes”), a distinctive feature seen in Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Patients present with constitutional signs/symptoms (“B symptoms”), including low-grade fever, night sweats, and weight loss, as well as contiguous lymph nodes abnormalities.
❌ Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with renal cell carcinoma, a primary neoplasm of the kidney. The presentation includes hematuria, palpable flank mass, flank pain, fever, and weight loss, as well as a variety of paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., ectopic EPO, ACTH, renin production).
❌ Keratin pearls and intercellular bridges:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Patients may present with cough, hemoptysis, bronchial obstruction, and wheezing, as well as the ectopic production of PTHrP.
✅ Abundant mucin-secreting, signet ring cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sheets of malignant cells invading the stroma and concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with serous cystadenocarcinoma, a surface epithelial ovarian cancer. Patients with ovarian cancer may present with acute symptoms (e.g., pleural effusion, bowel obstruction) or chronic (e.g., abdominal symptoms, pelvic heaviness). Anemia, however, is not typical.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to abdominal pain that started suddenly several hours ago. Two hours ago, the patient felt a sudden, sharp pain in the lower abdomen during a routine workout at the gym. Since then, she has felt nauseated and vomited twice. Medical history is unremarkable. She denies any trauma or history of similar symptoms, vaginal bleeding, unprotected sexual intercourse, or history of sexually transmitted diseases. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 127/74 mmHg. On physical examination, there is no guarding, but severe, right adnexal tenderness is noted. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Doppler ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ovarian torsion and a thin-walled, unilocular cystic mass filled with anechoic fluid is visualized. The patient subsequently undergoes ovarian cystectomy and detorsion. The results of the histopathological examination are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy woman is presenting with ovarian torsion which is most commonly associated with a physiologic cyst (e.g. functional cyst) or a neoplasm. The ultrasound demonstrates a thin-walled, unilocular cystic mass filled with anechoic fluid, favoring the diagnosis of a benign lesion. Additionally, the histopathological examination demonstrates cuboidal non-ciliated epithelium resembling ovarian surface epithelium with underlying stroma containing fibroblasts, which is consistent with serous cystadenoma.  

Serous and mucinous cystadenomas are very common benign, epithelial, ovarian neoplasms. They are usually asymptomatic and may be found incidentally on physical examination or imaging. If the mass becomes large enough, it may present with pelvic pressure or pain, bloating, urinary symptoms or lead to ovarian torsion. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, are larger, and are less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, both are lined with columnar epithelial cells, whereas mucinous cystadenomas cells contain abundant amounts of mucin. The stroma of both types of benign lesions usually contains spindly fibroblasts.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mucinous cystadenoma:
Incorrect: Mucinous cystadenoma is a common benign ovarian tumor. Similar to serous cystadenoma, it is usually thin-walled, uni- or multilocular, ranging from 5 to < 20 cm in size. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, and are larger and less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, the cysts are lined by columnar epithelial cells with abundant intracellular mucin. This patient’s histological results favor the diagnosis of serous cystadenoma.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Serous cystadenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mature cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: A mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is a benign germ cell tumor that often contains elements of differentiated germ cell layers including ectoderm (e.g. hair follicles), mesoderm (e.g. muscle), and endoderm (e.g. lung). On imaging, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and areas of acoustic shadowing. This patient’s imaging and histopathological results favor another diagnosis.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: flickr
❌ Endometrioma:
Incorrect: An endometrioma or "chocolate cyst" is a benign tumor that arises from the ectopic growth of endometrial tissue. Patients with endometriosis often complain of dyschezia, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. On ultrasound, it appears as a complex mass containing homogeneous internal echoes often described as "ground glass." This patient has none of these features.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Serous cystadenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Serous cystadenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial ovarian neoplasm. Patients with ovarian cancer may be asymptomatic or present with bloating, urinary symptoms, early satiety, pelvic or abdominal pain, bowel obstruction, pleural effusion, and venous thromboembolism. Macroscopically, the tumor appears as a solid, hemorrhagic, and necrotic mass. Microscopically, it may be high or low grade, and papillary and psammoma bodies are usually seen. A malignant epithelial ovarian tumor is seen in women older than 40 years of age and would be unlikely in this young female.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to uterine bleeding and breast tenderness. Over the past 2 months, the patient has noted occasional bloody spotting on her underwear which requires using multiple pads throughout the day. In addition, she noticed her breasts have become tender and mildly swollen. She has no urinary symptoms. Menopause occurred 5 years ago. The patient’s last Pap smear 1 year ago was normal. Family history is remarkable for breast cancer in her mother at age 65 and diabetes mellitus in her father. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, both breasts appear engorged but without expressible discharge. Vaginal examination is normal other than minimal blood in the vaginal vault. Pelvic examination reveals a left-side adnexal mass. Laboratory tests show the following:


The patient’s mass is most likely predominantly composed of which the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a thecoma, a subtype of sex cord-stromal tumors. Definitive diagnosis can only be made by histopathological analysis. Thecomas are benign, solid, and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. The tumors are usually seen in postmenopausal women. Thecomas may produce estrogen and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding, and up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, the tumors appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells.  

Of note, some tumors may be pure stromal tumors (e.g. thecoma) and others mixed (e.g. thecoma fibroma). The same goes for sex cord tumors (e.g. Sertoli cell tumor vs. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). The hormonal production pattern and associated markers depend upon the cell types present.




Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Thecoma

Option Analysis

✅ Theca cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulosa cells:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. Granulosa cell tumors include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors do often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) in adults and sexual precocity in children. However, inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors and would be elevated, unlike in this patient.
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibromas are the most common amongst sex cord-stromal tumors. Pure fibromas are benign solid tumors, are typically unilateral, and are not hormonally active, distinguishing them from this patient’s presentation. They occur primarily in postmenopausal women. Rarely, the tumor may lead to ascites and pleural effusion, a constellation of symptoms known as Meig syndrome. Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) may be elevated.
❌ Undifferentiated germ cells:
Incorrect: Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that is composed of undifferentiated germ cells. It is commonly seen in adolescents and young adults but rarely in the elderly. The presentation includes a rapid increase in abdominal girth and pain due to torsion or rupture with hemoperitoneum. Menstrual abnormalities are also seen if the tumor is hormonally active. Dysgerminomas may contain syncytiotrophoblastic cells that produce placental alkaline phosphatase, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) that can be used for monitoring. hCG production is also possible. This patient’s laboratory findings suggest a different diagnosis.
❌ Cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts:
Incorrect: Non-gestational choriocarcinoma is a rare and highly malignant type of ovarian germ cell tumor. The placental origin is far more common than ovarian origin. Those of ovarian origin arise from the extraembryonic differentiation of malignant germ cells, which differentiate to trophoblastic structures. Essentially, all choriocarcinomas produce hCG, which may lead to precocity in girls and/or irregular vaginal bleeding. Serum levels of hCG are used for monitoring response to treatment. This patient’s hCG is negative.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of weight loss, increased appetite, and palpitations. The patient’s symptoms began around 5 weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and type I diabetes mellitus, managed with cetirizine as needed and insulin, respectively. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral eyelid lag and a mildly enlarged thyroid. Examination of the testes reveals a solid mass on the left testicle that fails to transilluminate. Laboratory testing is ordered and reveals the following:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone  0.2 µU/ml 
 Thyroxine (T4)  37 µg/dL 
 Triiodothyronine (T3)  170 mg/dL 

Histological analysis of the patient’s testicular mass would likely reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm
Tumor cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid

questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with a testicular mass, clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism, as well as laboratory testing demonstrating a reduced TSH and elevated T4 level. These findings are concerning for testicular choriocarcinoma.

Choriocarcinoma is a rare and aggressive form of testicular cancer that often metastasizes hematogenously to the brain and lungs. It most often affects young men between 20-35 years of age. The cancer is composed of cytotrophoblasts, which are immature cells with a central nuclei and pale cytoplasm, and syncytiotrophoblasts, which are more differentiated cells with multiple nuclei and a darker cytoplasm.

Laboratory testing will show elevated ꞵ-hCG levels but normal placental alkaline phosphatase and alpha-fetoprotein levels. The alpha subunit of ꞵ-hCG is structurally similar to luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). As a result, patients with choriocarcinoma can develop gynecomastia, due to hyperestrogenism secondary to FSH and LH activation, and hyperthyroidism (e.g., heat intolerance sweating, palpitations, eyelid lag). Furthermore, patients can develop hemoptysis, if there is lung metastasis, and neurological deficits, if there is brain metastasis.





Option Analysis

❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors typically result in elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and would not cause hyperthyroidism and hence would not account for the patient’s physical examination or laboratory findings.
❌ Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes cells with a “fried egg” appearance, which can be found in testicular seminomas. However, a testicular seminoma would not account for the symptoms of hyperthyroidism that this patient is experiencing.
❌ Presence of rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions:
Incorrect: Leydig cell tumors can produce androgens and estrogen, potentially causing precocious puberty and gynecomastia. Histological analysis of Leydig cell tumors would reveal Reinke crystals, which are eosinophilic rod-like structures found within the cellular cytoplasm. However, Leydig cell tumors would not manifest with symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
❌ Tumor cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Call-Exner bodies, which are found in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors are a type of ovarian cancer that most often affect middle-aged women. In contrast, this patient is a young male presenting with a testicular mass.
✅ Presence of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive pelvic discomfort over the past few months. Medical history is noncontributory, and she is in good health. The patient does not have a family history of malignancy, history of sexually transmitted disease, urinary symptoms, or bleeding. Last menstrual cycle was 5 years ago, and the last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits, other than a right adnexal mass upon palpation. Ultrasonography shows a solid right adnexal mass. The patient subsequently undergoes laparoscopy with excision of the mass. The specimen and histopathological analysis are shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arose from which of the following structures of the ovary?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Brenner tumor, which is an uncommon, solid, ovarian tumor composed of nests of transitional-type epithelium (urothelium) that resemble that of the urinary tract. Brenner tumors are composed of circular patches of cells with coffee bean nuclei. These tumors can arise from the surface epithelium or from urogenital epithelial cells that have been trapped within the germinal ridge. Although mostly benign, both malignant and borderline tumors have been observed.


Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This area is the oocyte (germ cell), which can give rise to germ cell tumors including dysgerminoma, teratoma, and yolk sac tumors. This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This area is the follicle, which is composed mainly of primitive sex cord cells and some stromal cells that support oocytes. The stromal cells include theca cells, fibroblasts, and Leydig cells, while the primitive sex cords include granulosa cells and Sertoli cells. Sex cord-stromal tumors may develop from the sex cords (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor, granulosa cell tumor), the stromal cells (e.g., thecoma, fibroma, Leydig cell tumor) or both (e.g., Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This area refers to the ovarian stroma. The stromal cells include theca cells, fibroblasts, and Leydig cells, while the primitive sex cords include granulosa cells and Sertoli cells. Sex cord-stromal tumors may develop from the sex cords (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor, granulosa cell tumor), the stromal cells (e.g., thecoma, fibroma, Leydig cell tumor) or both (e.g. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to intermittent sensations that her heart is racing. Over the past 2 months, the patient has experienced palpitations and lost 2.7 kg (6 lbs) without changes in her diet. The patient also notes she is sweating more than usual, which often makes her change her clothes to avoid embarrassment. Last menstrual cycle was 8 weeks ago, but it previously occurred every 28 days. The patient is sexually active with her partner, and they use condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 110/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the thyroid gland is normal and nontender without nodules. The breasts appear normal. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized uterus. A right-sided adnexal mass is palpated. Laboratory studies reveal TSH levels of 0.1 μU/mL. She subsequently undergoes laparoscopic unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The results of the pathohistological analysis are shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The constellation of symptoms of hyperthyroidism, low TSH, and an adnexal mass is consistent with struma ovarii, a type of specialized teratoma. The histology results demonstrate thyroid tissue found within the ovary.  

Struma ovarii is a specialized teratoma that is composed of mature thyroid tissue primarily. It may secrete thyroid hormones and lead to hyperthyroidism, but not all patients are symptomatic. The majority of cases are benign and managed by excision of the ovary or by unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. However, malignant transformation can occur. Another type of specialized teratoma is ovarian carcinoid,  which rarely produces carcinoid syndrome.  

Option Analysis

✅ Teratoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Choriocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Non-gestational choriocarcinoma is a rare and highly malignant type of ovarian germ cell tumor. The placental origin is far more common than ovarian origin. Those of ovarian origin arise from the extraembryonic differentiation of malignant germ cells, which differentiate into trophoblastic structures. Essentially, all choriocarcinomas produce b-hCG, which may lead to precocity in girls and/or irregular vaginal bleeding. Due to homology between the beta-subunits of hCG and TSH, hCG has weak thyroid-stimulating activity and may lead to hyperthyroidism. However, this patient's histological results favor another diagnosis.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism may occur in normal pregnancies due to homology between the beta-subunits of hCG and TSH. This occurs during peak concentrations at 10 to 12 weeks gestation. However, this patient consistently uses contraception and does not show any signs of pregnancy (e.g., breast swelling, uterine enlargement). Additionally, pregnancy does not explain the patient’s adnexal mass or the subsequent histopathological findings.
❌ Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor:
Incorrect: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of rare sex cord-stromal tumors that may be benign or malignant. They are capable of producing androgens resulting in virilization. They are not, however, associated with hyperthyroidism.
❌ Yolk sac tumor:
Incorrect: Yolk sac tumors are malignant ovarian germ cell tumors typically seen in young women. Patients commonly present with symptoms related to the presence of a pelvic mass. They do not produce hormonally active substances and are not associated with hyperthyroidism. AFP is the most commonly elevated tumor marker. Histologically, the tissue in these tumors resembles yolk sac tissue. The hallmark of yolk sac tumors is marked by the presence of papillary invaginations that surround a central vessel, known as Schiller-Duval bodies.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient was the unrestrained driver and suffered chest and abdomen contusions. She is hemodynamically stable and complains of mild abdominal pain. Medical history is unremarkable. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Serum β-hCG is negative. The chest radiograph is normal, and abdominal radiograph is normal other than an incidental finding indicated by the arrow in the picture below:

Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

The patient subsequently undergoes diagnostic laparoscopy, which shows the following histopathological finding:

Reproduced from: flickr

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy patient is presenting with an incidental calcified mass on abdominal imaging; the subsequent histological results confirm the diagnosis of a mature ovarian teratoma.  

Teratomas, a type of germ cell tumor, constitute up to 20% of ovarian tumors. They typically occur in the first 2 decades of life. The majority of teratomas are benign cystic teratomas while the immature, malignant subtype is rare. In general, the younger the patient, the greater the likelihood of the lesion being malignant.  

Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are also known as dermoid cysts, a name derived from the presence of cysts within the tumor that are lined by epidermis. These tumors are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, as well as other tissues. Most teratomas are discovered incidentally on abdominal x-rays or scans due to the presence of tooth-like structures within the tumor that produces foci of calcification. These neoplasms (especially the larger variants) are prone to cause ovarian torsion, since they increase the likelihood for the ovary to rotate on the axis of the infundibulopelvic and utero-ovarian ligaments and become fixed in a torsed position. A rare paraneoplastic complication is hyperthyroidism, which develops in teratomas containing thyroid tissue, a condition known as struma ovarii. Rarely, mature teratomas may transform into squamous cell carcinoma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Mucinous cystadenoma :
Incorrect: Mucinous cystadenoma is a common type of benign ovarian tumor. Similar to serous cystadenoma, it is usually thin-walled, uni- or multilocular, ranging from 5-20 cm in size. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, are larger and are less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, the cysts are lined by columnar epithelial cells with abundant intracellular mucin. This patient’s histological results favor the diagnosis of a mature ovarian teratoma.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Endometrioma :
Incorrect: An endometrioma or "chocolate cyst" is a benign tumor that arises from the ectopic growth of endometrial tissue. Patients with endometriosis often complain of dyschezia, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. On ultrasound, it appears as a complex mass containing homogeneous internal echoes often described as "ground glass.” Occasionally, it can lead to calcifications that can be visualized on x-ray. This patient had none of the symptoms of endometriosis, and the histopathology favors another diagnosis.

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Mature teratoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Theca lutein cyst:
Incorrect: Theca lutein cysts are a type of follicular cyst that arise due to high levels of β-hCG or sensitivity to β-hCG. It is associated with a gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestations, and ovarian hyperstimulation. Patients are usually asymptomatic but may present with virilization, hyperemesis gravidarum, preeclampsia, or thyroid dysfunction. This patient has none of these symptoms and had a negative serum β-hCG, eliminating this diagnosis.
❌ Ovarian carcinoma:
Incorrect: The vast majority of ovarian malignancies are derived from the surface epithelial cells of the ovary. Patients with ovarian cancer may be asymptomatic or present with bloating, urinary symptoms, early satiety, pelvic or abdominal pain, bowel obstruction, pleural effusion, and venous thromboembolism. Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common ovarian cancer. Macroscopically it appears as solid, hemorrhagic, and necrotic mass. Microscopically, it may be high or low grade, and psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) are usually seen. A malignant ovarian epithelial tumor is most commonly seen in women older than 40 years of age.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Over the past 2 months, the patient has noticed an increase in her abdominal girth despite losing 4.5 kg (10 lb) without changes in diet. She smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Menarche occurred at age 11, and her last menstrual cycle was 10 years ago. The patient’s last Pap smear was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, abdominal distention and shifting dullness are noticed. Pelvic examination reveals mild tenderness and a right-sided adnexal mass. Cancer antigen 125 is elevated. The patient is prepared for laparoscopy. Which of the following will most likely be found on histopathological examination of the patient’s adnexal mass?

choices.text: Sheets large cells with clear, glycogen-rich cytoplasm and occasional granulomas
Sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and concentric calcifications
Small clusters of round cells encircling a central cavity

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman with risk factors for ovarian cancer is presenting with abdominal ascites, pelvic pressure, fatigue, and an adnexal mass, raising concerns for possible ovarian malignancy. Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is a marker protein that is typically elevated in women with epithelial ovarian cancer and is seen in up to 90% of cases. From the answers above, only choice D describes serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most common type of ovarian cancer. Of note, CA-125 can be undetectable in cases limited to the ovary and elevated in a variety of benign conditions and other cancers. Therefore, it is mainly used in monitoring response to therapy.  

Ovarian cancers may arise from any of the 3 cell types found in normal ovary: the surface epithelium, the germ cells, and the sex cord–stromal cells. Surface epithelial tumors account for the majority of ovarian tumors, of which the serous subtype is the most common. Serous tumors are more commonly seen in women between 45 and 65 years of age. Risk factors for developing epithelial carcinomas of the ovary include older age, early menarche or late menopause, genetic mutations (e.g., BRCA1 and BRCA2), Lynch syndrome, nulliparity, and endometriosis. On gross examination, the mass is cystic, multilocular with serous/bloody fluid, and contains soft friable papillary projections. On histology, it is composed of sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and occasional concentric calcifications known as psammoma bodies.  

Mucinous tumors are another less common subtype of epithelial ovarian cancer that differ from serous tumors in a few aspects: the epithelium consists of mucin-secreting cells, the tumors are less likely to be malignant, and they are associated with a better prognosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Sheets large cells with clear, glycogen-rich cytoplasm and occasional granulomas:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with dysgerminoma, the equivalent of male seminoma. On histology, it is composed of sheets of uniform cells described as having “fried egg” appearance. Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd to 3rd decade of life. hCG is often mildly elevated. It is not associated with elevated CA-125.
❌ Primitive neuroepithelial elements:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with immature teratomas, a malignant tumor commonly diagnosed before the age of 20. This tumor is not associated with elevated CA-125.
❌ Transitional-type epithelium with “coffee bean” nuclei:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a benign Brenner tumor, a rare condition. It is usually unilateral and consists of transitional-type epithelium that resembles that of the urinary tract. On histology, it is often described as having “coffee bean” nuclei. It is not associated with elevated CA-125.
✅ Sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and concentric calcifications:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small clusters of round cells encircling a central cavity:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with granulosa cell tumors, a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumor. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and in children, sexual precocity. Inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors, not CA-125.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a sudden onset of acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain. Two hours ago, the patient felt a sudden, acute, sharp pain in the lower abdomen, followed by nausea and vomiting. Medical history is unremarkable. Serum b-hCG is negative. On physical examination, right adnexal tenderness is noted. Doppler ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ovarian torsion, as well as the presence of an ovarian mass. The patient subsequently undergoes ovarian cystectomy and detorsion. Which of the following features, if found on histopathological analysis, indicates a malignant entity?
questions.solution:
Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that constitute up to 20% of ovarian tumors. They typically occur in the first 2 decades of life. The majority of teratomas are benign cystic teratomas while the immature, malignant subtype is rare. In general, the younger the patient, the greater the likelihood of the lesion being malignant.  

Malignant (immature) teratomas, also called teratoblastoma, or embryonal teratoma, are often seen in young patients with a mean age of 18 years. Grossly, they appear bulky and solid with areas of necrosis. Similar to mature teratomas, they may contain mature tissue such as hair and teeth. On microscopy, their hallmark is the presence of immature elements or minimally differentiated tissue such as muscle, nerve, or other tissues. The most common finding is immature neural tissue. Patients with immature teratomas often present with similar symptoms to other ovarian neoplasms including abdominal enlargement or pain, ovarian torsion, or they may be asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally. In some cases, alpha-fetoprotein or lactate dehydrogenase may be elevated. Similar to other tumors, the prognosis depends on grade and stage at the time of diagnosis.


Option Analysis

❌ Hair follicles:
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, bronchial or gastrointestinal epithelium, as well as other tissues. While malignant transformation is possible, the presence of well-differentiated tissues (e.g. hair) indicates a benign lesion.
❌ Tooth-like tissue  :
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, bronchial or gastrointestinal epithelium, as well as other tissues. While malignant transformation is possible, the presence of well-differentiated tissues (e.g. tooth) indicates a benign lesion.
✅ Immature neural tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid tissue:
Incorrect: Struma ovarii is a type of specialized teratoma in which mature thyroid tissue is found within the ovary which may cause hyperthyroidism. The majority of cases of struma ovarii are benign, and the presence of thyroid tissue does not indicate malignancy.  
❌ Sebaceous glands:
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. Sebaceous glands typically arise from mature ectodermal tissue; well-differentiated tissue is invariably benign and malignant transformation is very unlikely.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents for evaluation of right groin pain, which he rates as a 6 out of 10 in severity. He states the pain has progressively worsened over the past month. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a right testicular mass that does not transilluminate or decrease in size when the patient lies flat. Laboratory testing reveals the following:

 Laboratory Value  Result  Normal Range 
 Placental alkaline phosphatase  0.92 ng/mL  < 1.85 ng/mL 
 α-fetoprotein  15 ng/mL  10-20 ng/mL 
 ꞵ-hCG  63 ng/mL  < 15 ng/mL 


With additional work-up, he is diagnosed with testicular cancer and undergoes a right radical orchiectomy. After resection, the testicular mass is observed to contain multiple areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histological analysis of the mass would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm
Presence of cells arranged in glandular and papillary structures
Presence of cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos
Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a painful testicular mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, as well as elevated ꞵ-hCG levels. He most likely has a pure embryonal carcinoma of the testicle.

Embryonal carcinomas are a type of germ cell tumor that occurs most frequently in individuals between ages 25-35 years. Pure embryonal carcinomas are rare and are commonly mixed with other types of germ cell tumors. Embryonal carcinoma usually presents as a painless, unilateral testicular mass, but it can sometimes be painful.

On gross examination, this type of tumor is usually hemorrhagic and necrotic. Under the microscope, it consists of immature, primitive cells which tend to arrange in glandular and/or papillary structures. In pure tumors, laboratory testing will show elevated ꞵ-hCG levels but normal placental alkaline phosphatase and α-fetoprotein levels. In contrast, in mixed tumors, α-fetoprotein levels may be elevated along with ꞵ-hCG.





Option Analysis

❌ Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer describes cells with a “fried-egg” appearance, which can be found in testicular seminomas. However, testicular seminomas are generally painless. Moreover, they tend to present with elevations in placental alkaline phosphatase, not ꞵ-hCG.
✅ Presence of cells arranged in glandular and papillary structures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos:
Incorrect: Koilocytes are cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. This histological presentation can be found in cervical cells infected with human papillomavirus (HPV).
❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors present with markedly elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, whereas this patient’s AFP level is within normal range.
❌ Follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Call-Exner bodies, which are found in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors are a type of ovarian cancer that most often affects middle-aged women.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 102/58 mmHg. Leukocyte count is normal. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a right ovarian mass. She subsequently undergoes laparoscopic unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. A histopathological analysis is performed and the results are shown below:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following tumor markers should be used to monitor the response to treatment?
questions.solution:
Yolk sac tumors make up 15-20% of all malignant ovarian germ cell neoplasms. Yolk sac tumors are aggressive malignant tumors typically found in the ovaries of young women and less commonly in the testes of young boys. Patients often present with abdominal pain and a pelvic mass. Tumor growth is often rapid with extensive intraperitoneal dissemination.  

Histologically, the tissue in these tumors resembles yolk sac tissue, with the presence of tubules lined by a simple cuboidal epithelium and may demonstrate papillary invaginations that surround a central vessel, which are known as Schiller-Duval bodies (as seen in this patient). These structures often resemble the glomeruli of the kidney. Because of the similarity of this tissue to yolk sac tissue, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is usually elevated in these tumors and can be used to determine response to treatment and to monitor for tumor recurrence. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) may also be elevated in yolk sac tumors, although this finding is less common and is not used for monitoring the response to treatment.



Option Analysis

✅ Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH):
Incorrect: Serum concentration of AMH may be elevated in granulosa cell tumors. Histology typically shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles.
❌ Inhibin:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of inhibin may be elevated in thecomas, granulosa cell tumors, and Sertoli-Leydig tumors, but not yolk sac tumors.
❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG):
Incorrect: Serum concentration of β-hCG may be elevated in embryonal cell carcinomas, ovarian choriocarcinomas, mixed germ cell tumors, and dysgerminomas. It is not elevated with yolk sac tumors.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):
Incorrect: Serum concentration LDH may be elevated in many types of cancer. LDH elevation is characteristically seen in dysgerminomas and less commonly occurs in yolk sac tumors. LDH is not used for monitoring treatment of yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of testicular pain and fullness, which have been ongoing for the last 3 weeks. A physical examination is performed and reveals the presence of a mass on the left testicle that does not transilluminate with light. Imaging and tumor marker analysis are performed, confirming the diagnosis of testicular cancer. He subsequently undergoes a radical orchiectomy. Post-operative pathological analysis of the testicle reveals a 6-mm tumor containing strands of hair and keratinous material. Which of the statements is most likely to be true regarding this type of malignancy?

choices.text: The likelihood of metastases to other organs is high
The tumor consists primarily of well-differentiated cells
The patient likely had elevated ꞵ-hCG levels prior to tumor resection
The tumor consists of immature cells from all three germ layers
The patient will receive adjuvant radiation therapy

questions.solution:
This boy is presenting with a testicular mass that contains strands of hair and keratinous material. He most likely has a testicular teratoma, which, in prepubertal males, usually consists of well-differentiated cells.

Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that contain tissue from all three germinal layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The tumor is composed of somatic-type tissue in various stages of differentiation and maturation. Teratomas can be sub-classified into two groups: mature teratomas and immature teratomas.

Mature teratomas contain well-differentiated tissue (e.g., skin, hair, nails) and typically present in children. The tumors are usually benign, and there have been few, if any, cases of metastatic disease in prepubertal males. In contrast, immature teratomas contain undifferentiated tissue, typically present in adults, and are usually malignant. Of note, unlike those found in adult males, teratomas in adult females tend to be benign.



Option Analysis

❌ The likelihood of metastases to other organs is high:
Incorrect: Testicular teratomas can present in both children and adults. In general, testicular teratomas found in prepubertal children are benign, contain well-differentiated cells, and have a low risk of metastasizing to other organs.
✅ The tumor consists primarily of well-differentiated cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient likely had elevated ꞵ-hCG levels prior to tumor resection:
Incorrect: Post-operative analysis, which demonstrates the presence of keratinous material and strands of hair, is suggestive of a testicular teratoma. Teratomas do not typically cause elevations in ꞵ-hCG levels. In contrast, other testicular tumors, such as choriocarcinomas and embryonal carcinomas, are more likely to cause elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.
❌ The tumor consists of immature cells from all three germ layers:
Incorrect: Teratomas consist of cells from the three germ layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. However, teratomas in pediatric patients typically consist of mature cells, whereas those in adult patients are more likely to contain immature cells.
❌ The patient will receive adjuvant radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Testicular teratomas in children consist of well-differentiated cells with low likelihood of metastases. As a result, patients are typically treated with orchiectomy without adjuvant radiation or chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to fatigue and difficulty breathing. The patient is generally healthy, but over the past few months, she has experienced progressive fatigue and dyspnea. She also has noticed an increase in her weight without changes in her diet. Her last menstrual cycle was 2 years ago; since then, she has had some mild hot flashes that have resolved without treatment. The patient’s last Pap smear 2 years ago was normal, and she has no history of a sexually transmitted disease or abnormal uterine bleeding. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, heart sounds are normal. There are decreased breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally and dullness to percussion. Abdominal examination reveals shifting dullness but no peritoneal signs. On pelvic examination, a right-sided, non-tender adnexal mass is noted but the rest of the exam is within normal limits. On ultrasound examination, a calcified hypoechoic mass is observed. Based on these features alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient is presenting with a triad of pleural effusion, ascites, and an adnexal mass, a classic presentation of Meigs syndrome, which is associated with a fibroma.  

Fibromas are the most common amongst sex cord-stromal tumors. Pure fibromas are benign solid tumors, usually unilateral, and are not hormonally active. They occur primarily in postmenopausal women. The fluid accumulation is thought to occur due to substances such as VEGF that increase capillary permeability. Removal of the fibroma results in resolution of the ascites and pleural effusion. Occasionally, the tumor can compress the round ligament of the uterus which produces a pulling sensation in the groin. Histology shows nests of spindle-shaped fibroblasts. On ultrasound examination, fibromas appear as a mass that may be hyper/hypoechoic, and they are often calcified and/or exhibit cystic degeneration. Treatment usually involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy or an ovarian cystectomy for women who desire preservation of the ovary.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fibroma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thecoma:
Incorrect: Thecomas are benign, solid, and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. They are usually seen in postmenopausal women. Thecomas may produce estrogen, and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding; up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, the tumors appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells. Thecomas are not associated with Meigs syndrome, as seen in this patient.
❌ Choriocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Choriocarcinoma is an invasive trophoblastic neoplasia composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts without villi. The most common presentation is antepartum vaginal bleeding. Other signs and symptoms include respiratory symptoms due to lung metastases, neurologic symptoms due to brain metastases, and acute abdominal pain due to bleeding intra-abdominal metastases. Choriocarcinoma can develop after any type of pregnancy (e.g., molar, abortion, etc.), though it rarely occurs coexistent with a normal intrauterine pregnancy. Since this patient is postmenopausal, this diagnosis is unlikely.
❌ Mature cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: A mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is a benign germ cell tumor that often contains elements of differentiated germ cell layers including ectoderm (e.g. hair follicles), mesoderm (e.g. muscle), and endoderm (e.g. lung). On imaging, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and areas of acoustic shadowing. 
❌ Granulosa cell tumor:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and sexual precocity in children. Inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors. This patient, however, shows none of these features.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of a painless right testicular mass. The patient first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago while showering, and he is not sure if it has been enlarging. Medical history is notable for right-sided cryptorchidism as a child, which was treated via orchiopexy at the age of 1. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 105/77 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a nontender nodule on the right testicle which does not transilluminate or decrease in size when the patient lies flat. After further diagnostic testing is performed, the physician suspects a testicular cancer and schedules an orchiectomy. Gross analysis of the tumor reveals a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis. Histological examination reveals the following:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the serum markers was most likely elevated prior to orchiectomy?
questions.solution:
This patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic testicular mass that demonstrates a “fried egg appearance” on histological analysis. These findings are consistent with those of a testicular seminoma, which can cause elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) levels.

Seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. Of note, a seminoma is the testicular analog of an ovarian dysgerminoma in women. Gross examination of a seminoma typically shows a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopic examination, tumor cells appear large with central nuclei surrounded by clear cytoplasm, and they are thus said to have a “fried egg” appearance. On laboratory testing, patients will have elevated PLAP levels, whereas alpha-fetoprotein and beta-hCG levels are typically normal.

In regards to prognosis, seminomas exhibit a slow growth rate, metastasize late, respond well to radiotherapy, and overall have an excellent prognosis.






Option Analysis

❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin:
Incorrect: This patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic mass on gross examination and cells with a “fried egg” appearance on histology. He most likely has a seminoma. Although some patients with seminomas may have elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (ꞵ-hCG) levels, elevations in placental alkaline phosphatase are more common.
❌ Alpha-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is elevated in yolk sac tumors and mixed embryonal carcinomas. Instead, this patient has a non-hemorrhagic, non-necrotic mass on gross examination and cells with a “fried egg” appearance on histology. Thus he most likely had a seminoma, which is not associated with elevated AFP levels.
✅ Placental alkaline phosphatase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adrenocorticotropic hormone:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can be associated with squamous cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and cancers of the central nervous systems. However, seminomas would not cause increases in ACTH levels.
❌ Parathyroid hormone-related peptide:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) is elevated in several malignancies, including squamous cell carcinoma and ovarian cancer. However, it is not elevated in testicular seminomas.

questions.text: A medical student is conducting research on the incidence of gynecological cancers across the world. He comes to note that in the United States, endometrial cancer has the highest incidence. By contrast, in Guatemala, he discovers that cervical cancer has the highest incidence. Which of the following factors regarding the United States best accounts for this difference?

choices.text: Lower prevalence of high-risk HPV strains

questions.solution:
It is important to remember that cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer worldwide, due to the lack of screening and availability of vaccines. However, in high socioeconomic countries like the United States, cervical cancer is less common and endometrial cancer takes the highest incidence. Screening for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cervical cancer is done with a Pap smear, along with high-risk HPV DNA testing. The utilization of the Pap smear has significantly improved our ability to detect cervical dysplasia and prevent its progression to cervical cancer.  

In the United States, ovarian cancer has the highest mortality rate, followed by endometrial cancer, and cervical cancer has the lowest mortality rate. However, the mortality rate for cervical cancer is higher in developing countries because of limited access to screening programs and the HPV vaccine.  

Option Analysis

❌ Better access to barrier contraception  :
Incorrect: Barrier contraception, such as condoms, can reduce HPV transmission, which in turn reduces the patient’s risk of developing cervical cancer. However, this factor is not the strongest explanation for the lower cervical cancer rates in the United States and other developed countries.  
✅ Greater access to screening tests:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lower rates of tobacco use:
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking or exposure to second-hand smoke can increase a patient’s risk of developing cervical cancer. However, cigarette consumption per year per person is actually lower in Guatemala than the United States.  
❌ Later onset of sexual activity:
Incorrect: Later onset of sexual activity is instead protective against cervical cancer. Moreover, better access to screening tests and vaccinations are the primary reasons why developed countries such as the United States have lower rates of cervical cancer than developing countries such as Guatemala.  
❌ Lower prevalence of high-risk HPV strains:
Incorrect: The high-risk HPV strains include 16, 18, 31, and 33. These strains can be found in both the United States and Guatemala. Instead, better access to screening tests and vaccination are the main reasons why the United States and other developed countries have lower rates of cervical cancer.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive lower back pain. He first noticed the pain a few months ago at the grocery store. It is most severe at night and is not relieved by rest, exercise, medication or change in position. He has not had any recent trauma. He also reports difficulty initiating urination and dysuria for the past 6 months. He is a retired veteran and lives alone. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for colorectal cancer in his father. Vitals are within normal limits. Neurological examination and straight leg raise test are normal. MRI of the lumbar spine is performed and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Irregular prostate on digital rectal examination

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic back pain which is worse at night, not relieved by rest or change in position, in combination with lower urinary tract symptoms and MRI showing vertebral metastases is consistent with metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma. 

Prostate adenocarcinoma is among the most common cancers in men worldwide and is more commonly seen in patients of African-American descent. The risk of developing prostate cancer increases with age, peaking between ages 65 and 74 years. Most prostate cancers are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis but may present with non-specific urinary symptoms (hematuria, difficulty initiating urine, dysuria and pain with ejaculation) and back pain (in advanced, metastatic disease). Bone metastases in men with advanced prostate cancer are usually osteoblastic (i.e. characterized by new bone formation). This finding is indicated by the red arrows in the MRI. The precise mechanisms by which prostate cancer tumor cells induce osteoblastic changes are uncertain but are believed to involve excess activation of osteoblast mitogens that induce bone growth.    

A nodular, asymmetric or indurated posterior prostate is observed on digital rectal exam (DRE). Peripheral posterior prostate (away from the urethra) is the most common location for prostate cancers; this phenomenon is the reason urinary symptoms occur late in the disease course, when the periurethral region becomes involved. Serum prostate specific antigen (PSA) may be elevated but is not specific for malignancy.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Paraspinal tenderness:
Incorrect: Paraspinal tenderness is commonly observed in lumbosacral strain, wherein the back pain is aggravated by physical exertion and relieved with rest and pain medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
✅ Irregular prostate on digital rectal examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced chest expansion:
Incorrect: Reduced chest expansion is a complication of ankylosing spondylitis. It causes chronic back pain in young adults which is relieved with exercise. It is unlikely in this elderly patient with lower urinary tract symptoms.
❌ Perianal anesthesia:
Incorrect: Perianal anesthesia is a clinical finding of cauda equina syndrome and other neurologic diseases involving the sacral spinal roots. It is a surgical emergency and is associated with marked neurologic disability (bilateral leg weakness, bladder bowel and sexual dysfunction). Straight leg raise is typically positive.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Inguinal lymphadenopathy is common in lower extremity infections, sexually transmitted diseases or cancers. Common associated cancers include skin of the trunk, rectum, anus and penis. The prostate gland drains into the iliac and paraaortic nodes, not inguinal nodes.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive lower back pain for the past 4 months. The pain is relatively constant, non-radiating, aching and interferes with his sleep at night. It is not relieved by rest or change in position. He also reports feeling tired all day and not being able to get out of bed without help. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows point tenderness at the level of L4-L5 vertebrae. Forward flexion does not alleviate the pain. A hard lump is palpated on digital rectal examination. Hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 10,000/mm3. Serum chemistry is shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   139 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium, serum  9.2 mg/dL 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  7 mm/hr 
 Creatinine  1.1 g/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  157 U/L 

Serum prostate specific antigen is 15 ng/mL. Further evaluation of this patient will show which of the following?

choices.text: Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy
Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray

questions.solution:
This patient with progressive lower back pain that is worse at night and is not relieved by rest and elevated prostate specific antigen (PSA) levels, in combination with point tenderness and a palpable hard lump on digital rectal examination (DRE), is most likely suffering from metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma.  

It is among the most common cancers in men worldwide and is more commonly seen in patients of African-American descent. It spreads via the vertebral venous plexus (Batson plexus) to the bones of the axial skeleton, like the vertebrae or pelvis, resulting in hip or lower back pain. The metastasis results in osteoblastic (bone forming) lesions in most cases. The precise mechanisms by which prostate cancer tumor cells induce osteoblastic changes are uncertain but are believed to involve excess activation of osteoblast mitogens that induce bone growth. Vertebral compression fracture and spinal cord compression may also occur less commonly. This patient should be evaluated with a radionuclide bone scan, which is effective in detecting osteoblastic metastases as foci of abnormal uptake throughout the skeleton. In the presence of osteoblastic lesions on bone scan, bone-specific alkaline phosphatase can also be elevated and can be used as a screening tool to detect recurrence after treatment. If bone scan is inconclusive, an MRI or CT scan can be used.  



Option Analysis

✅ Osteoblastic lesions on bone scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Although these patients present with long-standing bone pain, a normal serum creatinine and calcium levels make this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Blood culture growing Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus is commonly isolated from blood culture of patients with vertebral osteomyelitis, which usually presents with fever, back pain, and focal spinal tenderness. Although leukocyte count may be normal, ESR and CRP are elevated. It is unlikely in this patient with chronic back pain and a hard lump on DRE.  
❌ Ligamentum flavum hypertrophy on MRI:
Incorrect: Ligamentum flavum hypertrophy on MRI is a common finding in spinal stenosis. It usually manifests with radiating back pain which is relieved by bending forward (flexing). This patient’s pain is not affected by change in position.
❌ Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray:
Incorrect: Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray (bamboo spine) is a classic finding of advanced ankylosing spondylitis, which usually presents in young adults with insidious onset back pain. Associated enthesitis, dactylitis and extra-articular manifestations are common. It is unlikely in this elderly patient with a hard lump on DRE.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pelvic discomfort over the past few months. She states she generally feels well and denies any unintentional weight loss and fatigue. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and smoking 1 pack per day for 30 years. The patient is in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 37 years and denies any history of sexually transmitted diseases. Family history is notable for colon cancer in her father at age 55. Last menstrual cycle was 7 years ago. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a right-sided, non-tender adnexal mass is noted. Which of the following features would most likely indicate the presence of a malignant mass?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with pelvic discomfort and an adnexal mass. Adnexal mass can be simple or complex. The main concern in postmenopausal women who present with an adnexal mass is to exclude malignancy.  

Following a thorough history and physical exam, there are 4 steps that can assist in determining the management. First, an ultrasound should be obtained to determine if the mass is likely benign (simple cyst) or malignant (complex cyst). The differences in sonographic features are summarized in the table below. Complex cysts typically have internal vascularity, which can be seen on Doppler ultrasonography. As neoplastic cells proliferate and grow, their metabolic needs increase, resulting in increased blood vessel formation and growth.  

The next step is to determine if there is a physiological process that can account for the mass (e.g. hemorrhagic physiologic cyst). The third step is to determine if there are characteristics of a specific entity (e.g. endometrioma usually demonstrates echoes in a cystic mass). The last step is to determine if there is a need for a follow-up ultrasound or additional testing. A repeat of pelvic ultrasound is useful when physiologic processes are still in the differential diagnosis. An MRI should be considered if the results on ultrasound are equivocal.  

If the mass appears to be malignant, testing for serum CA-125 has a higher specificity for ovarian malignancy when combined with imaging. Lastly, surgical exploration is indicated if the initial evaluation demonstrated sufficient suspicion of a malignant adnexal mass.  



Option Analysis

❌ Round cystic shape on ultrasound:
Incorrect: A round or oval shaped cyst on pelvic ultrasound is indicative of a simple, benign cyst. In contrast, a cyst with solid components and thick septations requires further work up, due to the increasing chance of malignancy.
❌ Unilocular cyst on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Unilocular cysts are associated with benign ovarian processes, whereas the presence of multiple loculations and septations suggests a malignant ovarian process.
❌ Thin cystic wall on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Thin cystic walls are a common feature of benign, simple ovarian cysts. In contrast, the presence of thick septations can indicate a malignant process.
✅ Internal flow on Doppler imaging:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to increased facial hair growth. The patient states that over the past 6 months, hair started growing on her face and abdomen. She also describes mild pelvic discomfort that has minimal impact on her daily routine. Medical history is notable for a chlamydia infection at age 20, which was managed with antibiotics, and asthma, for which the patient takes albuterol and inhaled corticosteroids. She is sexually active with her partner of 6 months and uses condoms for contraception. The patient’s last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Menstrual cycles occur at regular 28 days intervals and last for 3 days of mild flow. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows coarse dark hair on the chin and abdomen. On vaginal examination, clitoromegaly is noted. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with the recent onset of virilization and normal pattern of menstrual cycles. From the answers above, only Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is associated with hyperandrogenism (regarding PCOS, see choice A).  

Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of rare sex cord-stromal tumors. These tumors are typically benign, but malignant behavior is also possible. They are usually seen in women in the 2nd and 3rd decades of life. On histology, the tumor is composed of tubules lined with Sertoli cells, and surrounded by stroma interspersed with Leydig cells. Macroscopically, they are yellow and lobulated, with a smooth surface. The tumor commonly produces androgens resulting in virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly). Estrogen production and side effects have also been observed, but this phenomenon is less common. AFP and inhibin tumor markers may be elevated. It should be noted that AFP is mostly associated with yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinomas.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of the ovary  



Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):
Incorrect: PCOS, the most common cause of infertility in women, is characterized by ovulatory dysfunction and symptoms of hyperandrogenism. The criteria to diagnose PCOS include a pattern of abnormal uterine bleeding for age, which is persistent for at least a year, as well as evidence of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne, hirsutism). While this patient is obese and is showing signs of excess androgens, the normal menstrual pattern essentially eliminates PCOS as a diagnosis.
❌ Adverse effect of medication:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are associated with a variety of side effects throughout the body including skin thinning and ecchymoses, Cushingoid appearance, acne, weight gain, striae, facial erythema, and hirsutism. While this patient shows some of these features, inhaled corticosteroids are less likely to cause systemic symptoms, and additional features would be expected.
✅ Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulosa cell tumor:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and sexual precocity in children. Virilization, however, rarely occurs with granulosa cell tumors.
❌ Thecoma:
Incorrect: Thecomas are benign, solid and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. They are usually seen in postmenopausal women. Thecomas may produce estrogen, and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding; up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, they appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells. This patient is young and instead showing signs of hyperandrogenism.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pelvic heaviness and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also discloses bloody spotting on her underwear, which has required intermittently changing throughout the day. The patient has had no urinary symptoms or weight loss. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient’s last menstrual cycle was 6 years ago. Her last Pap smear 2 years ago was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a right-sided adnexal mass is palpated. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe. Endometrial biopsy reveals an early stage, well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient subsequently undergoes excision of the mass. The histopathological analysis is shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with signs of excess estrogens (i.e., thickened endometrial stripe, spotting) along with an adnexal mass. The pathohistological analysis demonstrates a classic picture of Call-Exner bodies, confirming the diagnosis of a granulosa cell tumor.  

Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumor. They include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. Granulosa cells appear round, pale, with scant cytoplasm, and characteristic "coffee-bean" nuclei. Grossly, the tumors are usually large (> 12 cm), tan or yellow, and can be soft or firm. On ultrasound, the tumor appears as a unilateral, echogenic, septated, cystic or solid mass that may be similar to mucinous cystadenoma.  

These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism including abnormal uterine bleeding (due to endometrial gland hypertrophy), breast tenderness, and endometrial adenocarcinomas (due to uninhibited endometrial gland hypertrophy). In children, the elevated estrogen or progesterone levels may lead to sexual precocity. Virilization is also possible, but rare. Markers that may be found elevated in patients’ serum include inhibin, anti-Mullerian hormone, and CA-125.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) may be elevated in many types of cancer. LDH elevation is characteristically seen in dysgerminomas and less commonly in yolk sac tumors. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated LDH.
❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) may be elevated in embryonal cell carcinomas, ovarian choriocarcinomas, mixed germ cell tumors, and dysgerminomas. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated hCG.
❌ Alpha-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) may be elevated in yolk cell tumors, Sertoli-Leydig tumors, embryonal carcinomas, and immature teratomas. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated AFP.
❌ Testosterone:
Incorrect: Testosterone may be elevated Sertoli-Leydig tumors and granulosa cell tumors. Although this patient’s diagnosis is consistent with granulosa cell tumor, she does not show signs of excess androgens (e.g. hirsutism), and therefore an elevated testosterone level would be unlikely.
